No, it ain’t fish eggs. Instead, ROE means return on equity -- or more accurately, return on shareholders' equity.The gauge divides a company’s full-year net income by its shareholders' equity, then multiplies by 100 to get a percentage figure. IBD takes the average equity over the past two years. The result expresses how much profit it can generate for every dollar of net assets. IBD research into past big market winners shows a ratio of 17% or more as positive. Single-digit ratios could be cause for concern.ROE is a rough gauge for how efficiently management is putting capital to use and how its profitability is keeping pace with its growth as a publicly traded company.  As a company's equity grows, so does the challenge to maintain a high ROE. Earnings per share is another measure that weighs in on this question of ownership vs. profitability. But ROE does not take the number of shares into account.Where do you find it? Get a stock quote by using the search box at the top right corner of Investors.com. Under Stock/Company Data, you will find Annual ROE in the Company Fundamentals column. In addition, the minicharts presented with IBD’s Big Cap 20, Your Weekly Review and IBD 50 include ROE.Some companies often borrow debt to invest in new products and services to drive more profit. As a result, companies with high ROE sometimes also have somewhat elevated levels of debt.So as you perform your stock research, look at peer companies and compare their debt and ROE levels. If a target stock has a higher than group average ROE, and its debt is moderately higher, the two could be related.To be sure, a high ROE doesn’t compensate for unhealthy levels of debt. A long-term debt-to-equity ratio of 100% or more is considered high, even in certain industries known for heavy capital spending.If a stock has a low ROE (single digits and/or well below its group average) and very high debt, it could be a cause for concern.There is also a relationship between profit margins and return on equity. In some cases, you might allow for a below-peer ROE, if the company is churning out top-notch annual pretax margins. In general, annual pretax margin of 17% or higher is a sign of fundamental strength. You also want to see if a company's pretax margin is among the best in its industry.The average return on equity among current IBD 50 stocks is 28.4%. At the high end of the scale among companies that have thus far reported 2015 results, Campbell Soup (CPB) shows an unusually strong return on equity of 52.3%.That is well above peers like J.M. Smucker (SJM), with ROE of 7.2%, and even much larger players such as Kellogg (K), General Mills (GIS) and Kraft Heinz (KHC).Campbell’s pretax margins, 13.1% in fiscal 2015, are in line with these other food giants. Its long-term debt-to-equity ratio of 185% is certainly on the high side. It helps boost Campbell's ROE above a company like Smucker, which shows a long-term debt-to-equity ratio of 84%.

Packaged foods company B&G Foods (BGS) is looking good after acquiring frozen and canned food icon Green Giant. The stock is holding near an all-time high despite the volatile market, closing in on a 38.35 flat-base buy point. Also, its profit and sales growth look poised to accelerate, and its annualized dividend yield is a solid 4%. B&G had been in…

Thurgood Marshall seemed unlikely to become a successful civil rights lawyer.A hell-raiser at his Baltimore high school, he was punished by being forced to read the U.S. Constitution. It made him think about becoming an attorney after he graduated in 1925.But he wasn’t yet serious, getting suspended for pranks twice at Lincoln University in Pennsylvania before receiving a bachelor’s degree.The all-white University of Maryland law school rejected him. So he attended all-black Howard University in Washington, D.C., a year before it was accredited. He graduated first in his class in 1933 and opened an office in Baltimore.Soon an African-American was lynched, and Marshall would be thrown into the center of the civil rights storm.“He had to think positive throughout his entire career,” Wil Haygood, author of “Showdown: Thurgood Marshall and the Supreme Court Nomination That Changed America,” told IBD. “Everywhere he went in the 1930s to (the) 1950s as the civil rights attorney for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, the judicial deck was stacked against him at the local level. His only option was to appeal cases to the U.S. Supreme Court after each setback. He argued 32 cases before it, winning an astonishing 29.”In 1967, after a bitter confirmation battle in the Senate, Marshall became the first black justice of the Supreme Court.Marshall (1908-93) was born in Baltimore, where both sets of grandparents owned grocery stores. His father wanted to be independent of them and worked as a waiter, so money was usually tight.He moved the family to Harlem and five years later left New York and returned to Maryland.In elementary school, he did so well that he was skipped a grade.“Marshall was born into a family of articulate and assertive people,” wrote Larry Gibson in “Young Thurgood: The Making of a Supreme Court Justice.” “His father led vigorous dinner table discussions about current events and challenged his sons to support their positions with sound information. His mother spoke with polished diction and was determined that her sons would go to college and professional schools. With several aunts and uncles also providing guidance, the extended family expected him to succeed.”In the ninth grade, Marshall joined the high school debate club, directed by his history teacher, who taught him how to make persuasive arguments.At Lincoln University, he became the first freshman invited onto the debate team, and his skills grew as the group competed with the nation’s best at other colleges.Before going to law school in 1929, Marshall married fellow student Vivien Burey. They had no children by the time she died in 1955. Soon thereafter, he married NAACP secretary Cecilia Suyat. They had two sons who also became high achievers.At Howard, Marshall was mentored by the dean, Charles Houston. The young man finally became interested in civil rights in his last semester, when Houston asked him to research a case for the NAACP.After graduation in June 1933, Marshall and Houston took a road trip to New Orleans to document differences between black and white schools.

Marshall then returned to Baltimore to open his private practice in October. He one of only 34 black attorneys in Maryland out of 2,700.“The range and quality of clients Marshall acquired as a beginning lawyer in the Great Depression suggest that, if he had chosen to build a fee-producing law practice, he could have earned a very comfortable living,” wrote Gibson. Instead, he took the lower-income but more fulfilling civil rights cases. “He had developed work habits, attitudes and personal traits that would characterize his legal career. Colleagues marveled at his almost superhuman capacity to work long days for weeks and months without breaks.”Marshall developed the skills to talk with all types of people and listen to everyone as an equal.He was also able to disarm tense situations with wit and charm.Setbacks in his first civil rights cases involving criminal defense and discrimination by a college didn’t discourage him. He had his first victory (and sweet revenge) in 1935, when he joined Houston to win an NAACP lawsuit to integrate the University of Maryland law school. (Its new library in 1980 was named after Marshall).In 1936 the NAACP hired him as assistant special counsel in New York City, and his crusade began.In 1940 Marshall founded and directed the NAACP Legal Defense & Educational Fund.In 1944 he successfully argued a case before the Supreme Court that outlawed whites-only Democratic primaries.The same year, the highest court agreed that discrimination in housing based on race was illegal.After an initial effort to integrate graduate schools failed, Marshall’s court victory in 1950 led to opening them to black students.The next year, Marshall went to Japan and South Korea to investigate complaints of discrimination in military courts. His report on the problem led to reduced sentences for black GIs.Then came 1954.In his most far-reaching case at the Supreme Court -- Brown v. Board of Education -- Marshall challenged the Topeka, Kan., school board’s policy of having “separate but equal” facilities for whites and blacks.A majority agreed that separate schools were inherently unequal.“His victory in Brown stands as a singular, monumental achievement unmatched in its scope and social impact,” wrote Michael Davis and Hunter Clark in “Thurgood Marshall: Warrior at the Bar, Rebel on the Bench.”In 1961, President John Kennedy appointed Marshall to the U.S. Court of Appeals covering New York, Vermont and Connecticut.Over the next four years, Marshall wrote 150 opinions, including some protecting individuals from illegal search and seizure, and upholding the importance of not being retried on the same charges after an acquittal.In 1965 he became solicitor general, the nation’s highest-ranking lawyer, the first black to hold the position. Over the next two years, he won 14 of his 19 cases.Marshall was on the rise -- all the way to the Supreme Court, where in 1967 he landed President Lyndon Johnson’s nomination.Segregationists on the Senate Judiciary Committee put Marshall through five days of grueling hearings.“By the start of the third day, he had already been subjected to more questioning than any other nominee in history but kept his composure and didn’t allow himself to be drawn into controversial statements,” said Haygood. “For most African Americans in the first half of the 20th century, it was inconceivable that someone of their race would reach the Supreme Court in their lifetimes, but the Senate finally confirmed Marshall 69 to 11. The oath was administered by Justice Hugo Black, a former member of the Ku Klux Klan.“Marshall would remain unerringly true to his belief in equality and the First Amendment throughout his career.”Over the next 24 years, Marshall sided with the majority in some cases of affirmative action and busing, but few decisions dealt directly with race.Marshall made important contributions in other areas:A majority joined him to affirm that a plaintiff could have a jury trial in a lawsuit against a labor union.He formulated the standard of what evidence is considered relevant in financial securities cases.He argued that savings and loans were permitted to deduct losses from mortgage investments.He persuaded the other justices that mentally ill death row inmates were entitled to have a psychiatrist’s help in their appeals.As the court became more conservative, Marshall wrote more dissenting opinions, with a career total of 1,800, and earned respect for being principled.When Marshall retired in 1991, Sen. Orrin Hatch, Republican from Utah, said, “I don’t know of anyone on the bench who has had a more profound effect on American jurisprudence.”President George H.W. Bush nominated another African-American, Clarence Thomas, to replace Marshall.“No matter what direction the fight for equality now takes, it is clear all Americans have benefited from Marshall’s contribution to the nation’s democracy, not just the country’s black citizens,” wrote Davis and Hunter in 1992. “He used his legal talents to support the rights of the powerless and to make ‘equal protection of the laws’ more than just an idealistic legal phrase.”On July Fourth that year, Marshall accepted the Liberty Medal, given to those who have shown leadership in pursuit of “liberty of conscience or freedom from oppression, ignorance and deprivation.”Poland’s president, Lech Walesa, had been the first honoree.Though Marshall was in a wheelchair, his voice was fiery: “The battle has not been won; we have barely begun. ... America has no choice but to do better to assure justice for all Americans, Afro and white, rich and poor, educated and illiterate. Our futures are bound together.”He died the next January at 84.First black Supreme Court justice.Overcame: Strong opposition to his confirmation.Lesson: Practice keeping cool before getting grilled.“None of us got where we are solely by pulling ourselves up by our bootstraps. We got here because somebody ... bent down and helped us pick up our boots.”

Ernie Pyle was the pre-eminent war correspondent of his era. He rose to such heights through clarity of prose and an appreciation for the struggles faced by American soldiers during World War II.By writing with jarring detail, Pyle brought the war home to readers through his column, which ran six days a week via the Scripps-Howard Newspaper Alliance.“Ernie Pyle always wrote about what he could see,” Owen Johnson, associate professor emeritus at Indiana University and editor of “At Home With Ernie Pyle,” told IBD. “He called it ‘the worm’s-eye view.’ What he could see from where he was, that’s what he was going to write about. Pyle’s column grasped what one might call the simple but complicated essence of what war is about.”Pyle’s reporting in Europe, in particular, brought him great acclaim. He did it while putting himself at such risk that he died on the battlefield.What he left behind were stories of soldiers who would otherwise have remained anonymous.“There was always that connection with Ernie,” said Ray Boomhower, author of “The Soldier’s Friend: A Life of Ernie Pyle.” “Readers truly felt they could trust him and rely upon him.”Born near Dana, Ind., Ernest Taylor Pyle (1900-45) was the only child of Will and Maria Pyle.According to James Tobin in “Ernie Pyle’s War: America’s Eyewitness to World War II,” Will struggled as a farmer and with Maria “passed on decency and compassion, sensitivity toward others and a capacity for hard work.”Ernie had no desire to be a farmer. What he had was wanderlust and an attraction to more dramatic career pursuits.After a brief stint in the Navy Reserve, Pyle enrolled at Indiana University “with a single suitcase and an aimless ambition,” wrote Tobin.While on the Bloomington campus, Pyle developed his interest in journalism. He became editor in chief of the Indiana Daily Student before withdrawing one semester short of graduation to write for a small-town newspaper in the state.That impatience continued. “When he tired of his routine,” wrote Tobin, “he would just leave,” leaping to trips across the country and jumping from job to job.By 1923, Pyle was in the nation’s capital writing for the Washington Daily News. Things were looking up, especially when he landed a column covering aviation.In Pyle’s aviation writing, as in his later war reporting, he trumpeted the common man’s exploits.“Ernie made a specialty out of telling tales of the mail pilots’ feats of bravery and improvisation,” making them into “miniature narratives,” wrote Tobin.Pyle was gaining widespread recognition as a travel reporter.“His trademark topics were drawn from the concrete stuff of everyday life,” noted Tobin. “He studied unknown people doing extraordinary things.”For example, he wrote of an Alabama man who loved ancient history so much that he built -- and lived in -- a replica Roman temple.Pyle continued writing about his travel exploits until 1942. By then he was also reporting on the war, including the Nazi blitz of London while there in 1940. His wartime writing intensified after America’s entry in December 1941.“Pyle’s experiences profiling ordinary people in his aviation and travel reporting laid the foundation for his writing about ordinary soldiers during World War II,” said Boomhower.Pyle made his momentous mark with newspaper pieces about the war in Europe as a roving reporter for Scripps-Howard from 1942 through 1944.In his most famous column, “The Death of Captain Waskow” in January 1944, Pyle described the discovery of the body of a beloved Army officer, as well as other soldiers’ reactions:“Then the first man squatted down, and he reached down and took the dead hand, and he sat there for a full five minutes, holding the dead hand in his own and looking intently into the dead face, and he never uttered a sound all the time he sat there.”The Waskow column emphasized despair, love, camaraderie and resolve.Also, said Johnson: “The column was about dying, but Pyle’s writing put a personal face on it. It further showed how soldiers both dwelled on death and had to make their peace with it, and yet they went on fighting.“For me, one of the crucial elements is that, at the end of the column, after they had paid their homage to Captain Waskow, Pyle wrote: ‘We lay down on the straw in the cowshed, and pretty soon we were all asleep.’ ”Such prose was a Pyle hallmark. “He wrote the way one would write a letter,” said Johnson.In “Killing Is All That Matters” from December 1942, Pyle wrote: “The last of the comforts are gone. From now on you sleep in bedrolls under little tents. You wash whenever and wherever you can.”In “The God-Damned Infantry” in May 1943, he spelled it out: “Every line and sag of their bodies speaks their inhuman exhaustion.”His artistry especially glowed as Britain took German air assaults: “It was a night when London was ringed and stabbed with fire.”Tobin lauds Pyle for having “a keen ear for harmonies,” wrestling with word choice and cadence.“By 1942,” said Tobin, “he had become a master craftsman of short prose and simultaneously shaped a mythic role for himself: an American Everyman ready for war.”Pyle’s personal struggles made his reporting particularly challenging. He endured depression, exacerbated by the stress of wartime. Also, his wife, Geraldine, suffered from bipolar disorder. They had no children.Even so, Pyle was a voluminous writer, and his wartime columns now make up four volumes.By focusing on soldiers at war, Pyle endeared himself to his readers.“He put the spotlight more on the subjects he wrote about than himself,” said Boomhower. “He was humble. Readers gravitated toward him because he was not someone who liked to boast about himself or put himself above anyone else. His reporting reflected his upbringing here in Indiana.”Pyle’s focus on the day-to-day lives of GIs meant he rarely wrote about the politics of the war itself.His emphasis was connecting readers and the troops.“Pyle had a great respect for his subjects,” said Boomhower. “He never tried to hold anyone up to ridicule. He respected the individual and their story, which I think is lacking with some writers today.”In developing what Tobin describes as “a strange and inextricably intimate” bond with his readers, Pyle became one of the most famous Americans of his time.He was invited to meet with first lady Eleanor Roosevelt at the White House in November 1943, appeared on the cover of Time magazine in July 17, 1944, and was portrayed by Burgess Meredith in the 1945 movie “The Story of G.I. Joe.”Also in the thick of WWII, Pyle received the Pulitzer Prize for correspondence in 1944.“Readers trusted Pyle because he was honest,” said Johnson. “It was almost as if he had a video camera in his head. He told things the way they were.”After a break to recover from the stresses of war and to care for his wife, Pyle resumed his reporting in the Pacific Theater early in 1945.After surviving close calls, Pyle was killed on Iejima Island, part of Okinawa, Japan, on April 18, 1945, when Japanese machine gun fire hit him below the helmet. He was buried on the spot.Upon Pyle’s death, President Truman said: “No man in this war has so well told the story of the American fighting man as American fighting men wanted it told. He deserves the gratitude of all his countrymen.”The building housing the journalism school at Indiana University is named Ernie Pyle Hall.He retains an esteemed place in journalism history because of the quality of his writing and his integrity as a reporter, said Boomhower: “Pyle’s writings have stood up exceptionally well with time. There have been a lot of pretenders over the years, but there is really no one quite like Ernie.”Renowned correspondent of World War II.Overcame: Battlefield danger.Lesson: Act humbly and put the spotlight on others.“The drama and romance are here, of course, but they’re like the famous falling tree in the forest -- they’re no good unless there’s somebody around to hear.”

As far as most income investors are concerned, the steadier the payout the better. An added bonus: a high dividend growth rate. Here are five Dividend Leaders that offer both, as well as a yield that's well above the S&P 500's average 2.08% payout.All five score a Dividend Stability Factor of 1 on a scale from 0 (most stable) to 99 (most volatile) on a three- to five-year basis.

Philip Morris International (PM), which pays a 4.6% annual dividend, tops the list based on that measure. Its long-term dividend growth rate is 11%. The Marlboro maker on Dec. 9 boosted its quarterly payout by 20% to $1.02 a share, or $4.08 for the year.Analysts expect the tobacco firm's earnings to decline for a second straight year in 2015, before rising 5% next year. The stock is below a 90.18 flat-base buy point. It's up about 7% year to date, vs. the S&P 500's 2% loss.Pfizer (PFE), which also made the Friday column featuring high-yield drug stocks, is second, with an annualized payout of 3.7%. Like Philip Morris, its dividend growth rate is 11%. The stock is still below its 10-week and 40-week lines as it consolidates.General Mills (GIS) also has a long-term dividend growth rate of 11%. The cereal maker on Thursday announced a 33% increase in its quarterly payout to 44 cents a share. That works out to $1.76 on a full-year basis, for a 3.1% yield.The company also reported quarterly results that day that missed views on both the top and bottom lines. Shares fell 3% Thursday but found support at the 200-day moving average. The stock, up about 8% year to date, has been consolidating since early August.Coca-Cola (KO), which also pays a 3.1% annual dividend, has a long-term dividend growth rate of 9%. The beverage giant is an S&P 500 Dividend Aristocrat — companies that have increased their dividends each year for the past 25 years — and a top Warren Buffett holding. Shares are slightly positive this year.

Recent consumer IPOs were a more fitness-focused bunch than those of years past and have largely outperformed new-issue cohorts, offering a clue into who the hot newcomers may be when the current IPO chill starts to gradually thaw.Of the 15 consumer companies that went public in 2015, over half of them were tied -- directly or indirectly -- to the health and wellness trend. The Class of 2015 included fitness tracker maker Fitbit (FIT), gym operator Planet Fitness (PLNT) and SkinnyPop popcorn maker Amplify Snack Brands (BETR).“If you add fast-casual to your list, a lot of these have a focus on health,” said Kathleen Smith, co-founder of IPO research firm Renaissance Capital. “It resonates. Some of it is that the younger people realize they’re going to live longer and if you’re going to live longer you’ve got to be healthy and eat well and exercise.”Next up could be SoulCycle, an upscale spin-studio operator with a celebrity following. The prospective IPO, a popular choice for hipsters and workout junkies looking for an Instagrammable workout, most recently took its rave-like studio classes to SXSW, hosting "cardio parties" in partnership with Spotify.Even Fido’s in on it. July IPO Blue Buffalo (BUFF), which makes natural dog and cat food, is an extension of the consumer demand for more health-conscious, less-processed fare. And on the tech side, Mindbody (MB) went public last June with its class-booking and appointment-scheduling software for gyms and spas.One could even include the outdoorsy Duluth Trading (DLTH), a clothing company that caters to the “modern, self-reliant American” with plaid shirts and waterproof cargo pants for those who live a “hands-on lifestyle.”As more companies sprout from the soil of demand for health-conscious products, many of them tap the IPO market to fund growth, said Smith. That includes Shake Shack (SHAK), the fast-casual purveyor of antibiotic-free and hormone-free Angus burgers that went public at the start of 2015, and David’s Tea (DTEA), the Canadian chain that offers over 150 types of tea -- and not a single espresso drink.While a number of them are trading below their IPO prices, their performance has outpaced that of last year's new issues.Of the 170 companies that went public in 2015, the average return has been a 19.6% decline as of Monday's close, according to Renaissance Capital. But shares of the 15 consumer IPOs from last year, which includes all of the above names except Mindbody, have experienced a collective rise of about 1.1%.Planet Fitness, which went public at 16 last August, is up 18% from the market's low point of Feb. 11 this year to 15.60 by Monday's close. Amplify, which priced at 18 less than a year ago, has rebounded 44% from Feb. 11 to 13.60. Blue Buffalo has leapt 60% to 24.77, above its initial offering of 20 a share.That compares to the S&P 500's 11% rise in the same period. And investors have shown an eagerness to hop on board, though not all stocks have been cooperating with hopes for a fitter future.Within a few months of trading, Shake Shack’s stock more than quadrupled to a high of 96.75, and Fitbit more than doubled from its initial offering price. But they collapsed soon after that. Shake Shack lost two-thirds of its value and Fitbit three-fourths. Both are essentially flat since Feb. 11.“The investor interest is very high in fitness (and) healthy eating, but I think people struggle with exactly how to play the trend, as it is really relatively broad-based,” said Piper Jaffray analyst Sean Naughton, who covers Planet Fitness, Amplify and other consumer stocks.Plus, recent market volatility has put a damper on enthusiasm for privately owned businesses looking to take to the market. Only seven companies have gone public this year, said Renaissance Capital's Smith, vs. 28 during the same time frame in 2015.SoulCycle filed last July to go public but has yet to start trading. The company declined to comment, as it remains in a quiet period.“I think, overall, (SoulCycle has) performed rather well," said Smith. "It’s not like there isn’t competition in this area."The New York City-based chain raked in $112 million in 2014 revenue from its 38 locations, growing sales by nearly 49% from the prior year.But if the current market rally continues, the window for IPO issuance might be on the verge of reopening, after closing in December.Smith predicts that investors will see a trickle of companies ready to start trading sometime in April. With it might come names like SoulCycle or Honest Company, the baby and home product company founded by actress Jessica Alba.“When the market opens up, it will not be a tsunami wave of IPOs,” said Smith. "(It will be) slow, steady, below-average."She expects that health care, technology and consumer companies will likely lead the new-issue market this year, with a similar health-bent possibly flowing throughout."The SoulCycles and Honest Companies -- we'll see more of it," she said. "(And) more fast casuals."But as competition heats up, smaller companies riding the health and wellness trend -- newly public or not -- have to watch out for traditional heavyweights fighting back.Legacy names like General Mills (GIS), Kroger (KR) and Target (TGT) have have been adapting to the consumer shift toward natural and organic foods, putting pressure on the likes of Whole Foods Market (WFM), Sprouts Farmers Market (SFM) and others."Generally speaking, the better-for-you food players and the better-for-you grocery stores -- they’ve under-performed their traditional peers, really over the last eight months," said Piper Jaffray's Naughton.Image provided by Shutterstock.

Google-owner Alphabet (GOOGL) has snared iPhone maker Apple (AAPL) as a customer for its Google Cloud Platform, a deal that could help Google's service catch up with industry leader Amazon.com (AMZN), says an industry note from Pacific Crest Securities on Thursday.Amazon unit Amazon Web Services (AWS) is now the biggest provider of infrastructure as a service (IaaS), where customers rent computer servers and data storage systems via the Internet. Microsoft (MSFT) and Alphabet's Google rank next.Apple signed a contract worth between $400 million and $600 million to use Google's Cloud Platform, according to CRN. Apple now uses cloud services from Amazon and Microsoft, but intends to end its reliance on all its rivals in the next few years, as it builds its own data centers, according to Re/Code.While Apple has reportedly used AWS historically for iCloud, "the more surprising shift is from Apple to Google, which are odd bedfellows given the two companies' mudslinging and competition in other areas," wrote Pacific Crest Securities analyst Evan Wilson. "Did Google throw in free cloud as a way to renegotiate the search contract? Definitely adds to the perception of Google's momentum," Wilson added.The deal has not been confirmed by Google or Apple, but Apple did disclose its reliance on AWS and on Microsoft's Azure in a 2014 white paper.The alleged Apple-Google accord would help "Google Cloud Platform catch up to Amazon and Microsoft -- at least in terms of perception -- as a real third player in the space instead of a distant third. Google has done similar deals with Snapchat, PricewaterhouseCoopers, General Mills (GIS) Coca-Cola (KO), HTC and Best Buy (BBY)," said Wilson.In total, the cloud opportunity is big enough for all three Internet powerhouses, said Wilson, who estimated "a potential $25 billion windfall opportunity in cloud services for Amazon, Microsoft and Google, collectively."While AWS has been the biggest IaaS price-cutter of the last decade, Google Cloud Platform (GCP) has been aggressive since moving into the market. Google slashed prices in March 2014, October 2014 and May-June 2015, Goldman analyst Heather Bellini said in an industry report last month.Goldman Sachs says that the top three service providers are gaining share as Verizon Communications (VZ),  Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) and others exit the public IaaS market and focus on private clouds.Goldman Sachs estimates that AWS' revenue will hit $12.5 billion in 2016, up from $7.88 billion last year.Apple stock was down a fraction in midday trading in the stock market today, near 106. Alphabet was up a fraction, near 760, while Microsoft stock was also up a fraction, near 55. IBD 50 stock Alphabet gets a best-possible Composite Rating of 99 from IBD. Microsoft has a 75 and Apple a 70.Image provided by Shutterstock.

Dividend payers aren't just providing income, they are also providing breakouts from bases.General Mills (GIS) popped 2% Thursday, closing just above a 59.97 buy point. Volume was lower than average, however. The company has an annualized dividend yield of 3%.The cereal maker does a lot more than cereal now, with its ready to eat (RTE) cereal category accounting for just 20% of net sales in 2015.General Mills just presented at the Consumer Analyst Group of New York (CAGNY) conference on Feb. 16, where one of the areas of growth mentioned was the away-from-home market. That's over half of U.S. food and beverage expenditures. Specifically, food based on convenience is seen as a market growth opportunity. Snack bars, yogurt, individually packaged cereal, all play into the space.Another area of growth mentioned at the conference was the natural and organic category.The acquisition of Annie's has helped in this regard, and the company announced three new cereals from the organic brand.Procter & Gamble (PG) is a stalwart of the S&P 500 Dividend Aristocrats, with a current dividend yield of 3.2%. The stock is approaching a buy point of 83.10 from a year-long cup with handle.The consumer-goods giant has a market capitalization above $200 billion but does have some issues with growth.Three-year earnings growth for the company has been flat, and estimates for the 2016 fiscal year show a decline in profits. Revenue has seen declines for the past seven quarters.Waste Management (WM) is still in buy range from a cup with handle with a 55.38 buy point. The pollution control company has also had a recent decline in revenue growth but still shows a three-year earnings growth record of 9% and eight consecutive quarters of earnings growth.The company has a dividend yield of 2.7%.

Stock futures deepened their early losses ahead of Tuesday's open after a weaker-than-expected September durable goods report. Dow futures traded down 56 points and were falling. S&P 500 futures slipped 7.7 points.
Nasdaq futures, which had pared losses over the past hour, reversed and fell 11 points below fair market value.
The stock market today faces a busy session. The Federal Open Market Committee swings into its two-day meeting in Washington, with a policy announcement due out Wednesday afternoon.
A great many investors will be tuned to the aftermarket session, when Apple (AAPL) is scheduled to report fiscal Q4 results.

Economic news opened with durable goods orders, which slipped 1.2% in September, according to the Commerce Department. That was a bit worse than projections for a 1% decline. The department also revised August's decline down to 3% from 2.3%. Minus transportation, orders dipped 0.4%, down from August's flat performance and deeper than the projected 0.1% slip.

Case-Shiller reports its 20-City Composite Home Price Index for August at 9 a.m. ET. Researcher Markit releases its preliminary purchasing managers index estimate for U.S. services at 9:45 a.m. The Conference Board plans to report its October Consumer Confidence index at 10 a.m.
Earnings action was thick and heavy rolling toward Tuesday's open.

Beleaguered German chip equipment maker Aixtron (AIXG) spiked 11%. U.K.-based big oil play BP (BP) added almost 2%. Big pharma names Merck (MRK) and Pfizer (PFE) rolled up 2% gains after reporting better-than-expected Q3 results.

On the downside, frac sand quarrier Hi-Crush Partners (HCLP) imploded 26% after missing earnings forecasts and suspending its cash distribution. Rent-A-Center (RCII) posted a 20% premarket meltdown — it missed Q3 revenue expectations and lowered its Q4 and full-year earnings guidance. Ford (F) slipped 3%. United Parcel Service (UPS) dimmed 3%.

Alibaba (BABA) rumbled up 10% before the bell, launching a premarket rally among many China-based stocks. The China-based diversified Internet play reported a 27% EPS gain and a 32% rise in revenue in its fiscal Q2 — both easily topped consensus forecasts. Mobile revenue rose 183%. Cloud computing and Internet infrastructure revenues rose 128%.

The company also announced that the Securities and Exchange Commission gave notice that it concluded its inquiry and no enforcement action would be recommended. Alibaba shares ended Monday about 6% below their 200-day moving average. The stock has climbed 33% from a late-September low, leaving it still 36% below its Nov. 2014 high and 12% above its Sept. 2014 IPO price.
Yahoo (YHOO) swept ahead 6% early Tuesday as investors accounted for the increased value of Yahoo's 15% stake in Alibaba. Yahoo remains deep in an 11-month consolidation.
Other China-based Internet plays caught some of Alibaba's premarket heat. JD.com (JD) and 500.com (WBAI) popped 5% each. Jumei International (JMEI) and Vipshop (VIPS) jumped up 3% apiece.

Chip developer Marvell Technology (MRVL) tanked 18% after announcing late Monday that PricewaterhouseCoopers had resigned as the company's accounting firm. Marvell in September announced an internal investigation into whether some revenue was recognized earlier than it should have been. Marvell shares have been in a steep correction since February.

Cummins (CMI) dived 9% after missing expectations on both its earnings and revenue lines in Q3. Management lowered its full-year revenue outlook to flat to down 2% vs. prior guidance for a 2% to 4% gain. The Columbus, Ind.-based diesel engine maker also announced it would lay off up to 2,000 workers. Shares have been in a deepening decline since June 2014.
Among leaders, IBD 50 stocks were relatively quiet, with more than 80% of the group unmoved in premarket trade.

Among gainers, Cirrus Logic (CRUS) rose 2% after toppling 13% in heavy trade on Monday. No stock posted a decline of more than 0.3%.Stock futures deepened their early losses ahead of Tuesday's open after a weaker-than-expected September durable goods report. Dow futures traded down 56 points and were falling. S&P 500 futures slipped 7.7 points. Nasdaq futures, which had pared losses over the past hour, reversed and fell 11 points below fair market value.The stock market today faces a busy session. The Federal Open Market Committee swings into its two-day meeting in Washington, with a policy announcement due out Wednesday afternoon.A great many investors will be tuned to the aftermarket session, when Apple (AAPL) is scheduled to report fiscal Q4 results.Economic news opened with durable goods orders, which slipped 1.2% in September, according to the Commerce Department. That was a bit worse than projections for a 1% decline. The department also revised August's decline down to 3% from 2.3%. Minus transportation, orders dipped 0.4%, down from August's flat performance and deeper than the projected 0.1% slip.Case-Shiller reports its 20-City Composite Home Price Index for August at 9 a.m. ET. Researcher Markit releases its preliminary purchasing managers index estimate for U.S. services at 9:45 a.m. The Conference Board plans to report its October Consumer Confidence index at 10 a.m.Earnings action was thick and heavy rolling toward Tuesday's open.Beleaguered German chip equipment maker Aixtron (AIXG) spiked 11%. U.K.-based big oil play BP (BP) added almost 2%. Big pharma names Merck (MRK) and Pfizer (PFE) rolled up 2% gains after reporting better-than-expected Q3 results.On the downside, frac sand quarrier Hi-Crush Partners (HCLP) imploded 26% after missing earnings forecasts and suspending its cash distribution. Rent-A-Center (RCII) posted a 20% premarket meltdown — it missed Q3 revenue expectations and lowered its Q4 and full-year earnings guidance. Ford (F) slipped 3%. United Parcel Service (UPS) dimmed 3%.Alibaba (BABA) rumbled up 10% before the bell, launching a premarket rally among many China-based stocks. The China-based diversified Internet play reported a 27% EPS gain and a 32% rise in revenue in its fiscal Q2 — both easily topped consensus forecasts. Mobile revenue rose 183%. Cloud computing and Internet infrastructure revenues rose 128%.The company also announced that the Securities and Exchange Commission gave notice that it concluded its inquiry and no enforcement action would be recommended. Alibaba shares ended Monday about 6% below their 200-day moving average. Apple (AAPL) made Goldman Sachs' list of good and bad stocks to own when the Federal Reserve hikes interest rates.

Central bankers meet this week to discuss whether to lift the benchmark rate. While a September increase was seen as a sure bet a few months ago, recent global turmoil and mediocre U.S. data have prompted some analysts to expect a hike later.

The Cupertino, Calif.-based tech giant, was placed on the good list because of its strong balance sheet, Bloomberg reported. Some of the other companies making the grade ranged from tech to food to finance.
They are: Google (GOOGL), Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG), Wells Fargo (WFC), Priceline Group (PCLN), PepsiCo (PEP), BlackRock (BLK), Oracle (ORCL), Kinder Morgan (KMI) and Dollar Tree (DLTR).
On the other hand, companies with a lot of floating-rate debt should be avoided when the Fed hikes rates, because their financing costs will rise, Goldman Sachs analysts said in a report last week.
Despite its enormous sums of cash and overall balance sheet strength, Apple also has a lot of floating-rate debt, according to Goldman.

The companies that made it onto the not-so-great stocks list include: McDonald's (MCD), eBay (EBAY), MetLife (MET), Monsanto (MON), Coca-Cola (KO), General Motors (GM), Johnson & Johnson (JNJ), Allergan (AGN), Chevron (CVX), Time Warner (TWX), Ford Motor (F) and General Mills (GIS).

The somewhat schizophrenic listing of Apple in the Goldman Sachs report didn't faze investors. Apple shares rose 1%, finishing at 115.31 on the stock market today, helped by early indications that its latest iPhone models are seeing high demand.

Kroger (KR) on Thursday said most of its shoppers buy at least some organic or natural food, underscoring how mainstream the category has become.

The top U.S. supermarket company, parent to Kroger, Ralphs, Kwik Shop, Fred Meyer and other chains, delivered strong second-quarter earnings, led by surging sales of organic and natural food and recent acquisitions.
"Well over half of our (in-store) customers will buy something" in the category, CEO Rodney McMullen said on a post-earnings conference call with analysts. "That continues to increase."
"It's really all customer types. It's not specific to one type of customer by any means," he added.
Kroger is not the only traditional food player pushing into natural foods.
General Mills (GIS) on Monday said it would buy Annie's (BNNY), a packaged natural foods maker, for $820 million.

On Aug. 18, Kroger completed its $237.7 million purchase of online vitamin, supplement and organic grocery retailer Vitacost. McMullen said on Thursday's call that it bought Vitacost primarily for its e-commerce platform, which ships healthy food and supplements to homes nationwide.
With Kroger and other traditional grocers making a big push into natural and organic food, that's undercut pure-play natural foods retailers like Whole Foods Market (WFM) and Sprouts (SFM).
Kroger itself acknowledged on the call that natural foods margins are getting squeezed.
Organic and natural food makers WhiteWave (WWAV), Hain Celestial (HAIN) and Boulder Brands (BDBD) are independent, but sales are growing fast and there's plenty of takeover buzz.
"For Kroger, this is now a $4 billion to $5 billion category and growing at a double-digit rate," Jefferies analyst Mark Wiltamuth told IBD.

In an Aug. 14 report after meeting with Kroger, Wiltamuth said top management told him natural/organic is "the biggest growth story within Kroger. Kroger is seeing interest in this category across demographic lines — a sign that a broader shift toward healthier eating is driving the category momentum."
Kroger's Q2 earnings per share minus items rose 17% vs. a year earlier to 70 cents, a penny better than expected.
Revenue grew 11.4% to $25.3 billion, beating views for $24.9 billion, boosted by its January acquisition of the upscale Harris Teeter chain. Same-store sales rose 4.8%.
"Their identical store sales growth accelerated from the first quarter. They are clearly hitting on all cylinders," Wiltamuth said.
The supermarket chain raised its full-year 2014 EPS guidance to $3.22-$3.28, up from $3.19-$3.27 earlier. The new midpoint is a bit below the consensus of $3.28.
"They could be guiding conservatively, but they have a long history of hitting consensus," said Barclays analyst Meredith Adler.
Still she likes Kroger's prospects.

"They have said their Simple Truth natural foods label will be a billion-dollar brand by the end of the year," she said, adding, "They have a lot of data about customers and try to be really responsive."
Adler has an equal weight rating on Kroger with a 48 price target, but added, "I may have to revisit that."

Kroger shares rose 30 cents to 52.17. The IBD 50 fell 0.7%. Volume fell across the board. The day's negative reversal was a reminder that this market is in correction.…

Felix "Doc" Blanchard was on a training mission over England in 1959 when it happened: The oil line in his F-100 ruptured, engulfing the plane in smoke and flames.Ordered to follow protocol and eject, Blanchard, with a village beneath him, refused.Instead, he took the burning plane in for a safe landing away from the town, then fled the flames."I've never run so fast," he said.That's saying something.Just 13 years earlier, Blanchard (1924-2009) ran to fame on the Army football team, forming with Glenn Davis perhaps the most celebrated backfield in college history on the era's No. 1 powerhouse.Blanchard and Davis were consensus All-Americas in 1944, '45 and '46 — the only three-time All-America backfield teammates.They won the Heisman Trophy in successive years: Blanchard in 1945, Davis in '46.Into The End ZoneIn 1945 alone, they scored 37 touchdowns — 19 by Blanchard, 18 by Davis — in nine games.During their three seasons together, Army went 27-0-1 and won two consensus national titles.While the 208-pound Blanchard was pounding up the middle, Davis was outrunning defenders down the sideline, inspiring a New York sportswriter to call the pair Mr. Inside and Mr. Outside."Blanchard could run a 10-second 100-yard dash, and he probably weighed the equivalent of most linemen at the time," Kent Stephens, curator of the College Football Hall of Fame, told IBD. "He also played linebacker, punted and kicked off, and was a shot putter. He was an iconic figure."Laurels and statistics don't fully explain Blanchard and Davis' full impact on America in the war-torn 1940s. In a time when the country was desperate for sports heroes, they fit their roles perfectly as West Point football stars.Their faces appeared on the covers of Time and Life magazines.Their exploits were shown on newsreels.Their games were broadcast to servicemen across the globe.They even played themselves in a 1947 Hollywood biopic, "The Spirit of West Point.""Everybody knew Mr. Inside and Mr. Outside," said Conrad Crane, a former professor of history at West Point and an author on military matters. "Everybody followed the team, everyone listened to Army games on the radio. Army was dominating everybody on the football field — it was a metaphor for how the war itself should go. Army was America's team. They boosted everyone."Soldiers, too. When German troops launched a desperate counterattack during the Battle of the Bulge in December 1944, American GIs identified themselves in the Nazi-infiltrated woods by whispering "Blanchard."If the man headed their way was a fellow American soldier, he replied, "Davis."The Wild Blue YonderBlanchard could've written his ticket after football — business, PR, coaching. Instead he became an Air Force fighter pilot and went on to fly a maze of combat missions in the Korean and Vietnam wars.He retired in 1971 as a colonel, then spent several years as the commandant of cadets at the New Mexico Military Institute."He had the world at his feet," Crane said. "And he decides to serve his country with a full military career."Blanchard grew up in Bishopville, S.C., the son of a country physician who had played fullback at Tulane. Doc's mother, Mary, was first cousin to Jim Tatum, head coach at North Carolina, Oklahoma and Maryland.By the time Doc — his nickname because of his dad — was 3, he was kicking the ball on the front lawn of the Blanchard home.When he 12, his dad predicted he'd be a better running back than the great Bronko Nagurski, a star at the time for the Chicago Bears.Doc was built like Nagurski.He already weighed 180 pounds in his early teens, when his parents sent him to prep school at St. Stanislaus College on the Mississippi Gulf Coast, 40 miles outside New Orleans.After a sensational high school career, he played a year at North Carolina for Tatum, then tried to enter the Navy's officer training program during World War II.Rejected because of poor vision, Blanchard joined the Army as a private before securing an appointment to West Point in July 1944.Lean Machine"Doc Blanchard was the best-built athlete I ever saw: 6 feet and 208 pounds at his peak, not a suspicion of fat on him, with slim waist, Atlas shoulders, colossal legs," Army coach Red Blaik wrote in his memoir, "You Have to Pay the Price."Blanchard was hardly a household name prior to Army's 1944 game against Notre Dame.After the Black Knights' 59-0 triumph at Yankee Stadium — the worst loss in Fighting Irish history — he was front-page news. "I've just seen Superman in the flesh," Ed McKeever, the Notre Dame coach, wired back to South Bend, Ind. "He wears Number 35 and goes by the name of Blanchard."Blanchard had no time to celebrate. Coming up was a date with dreaded rival Navy to decide the national championship.Spotting a chance to boost a war-weary nation, President Franklin Roosevelt requested that the game be moved from Annapolis, Md., to Baltimore as part of a war bond drive. The deal: Buy a war bond, get a ticket. Seventy thousand fans responded by flooding into Municipal Stadium for what was billed the Game of the Century. Legions of soldiers tuned into short-wave sets in Europe and the South Pacific."We came into that game, and it seemed like the whole country was either in the Army or Navy or knew and cared about someone who was," Blanchard said in Bill Pennington's book "The Heisman." "It was one of the times when a game just felt like more than a game."At the start of the fourth quarter, Navy trailed 9-7 but was on the move. Davis, playing safety in those two-way days, intercepted a pass, and Blanchard led Army on a nine-play, 52-yard scoring drive.Cresting Against NavyHe carried the ball seven times, accounted for all but four of the team's yards and ran over three Navy defenders for the touchdown. Army headed home with a 23-7 win and the national title.Gen. Douglas MacArthur fired off a cablegram from his Pacific base to Blaik: "The greatest of all Army teams — STOP — We have stopped the war to celebrate your magnificent success. MacArthur."Blanchard finished third in the Heisman voting that year, behind Ohio State's Les Horvath, the winner, and Davis.Blanchard's 1945 season was even better.Now a junior, he rushed for 722 yards, averaged a remarkable 7.1 yards per carry, scored 17 touchdowns, caught four passes for 166 yards and capped his season by scoring three touchdowns in a 32-13 victory over Navy.It didn't end there for the junior. He also was the national shot-put champion and a sub-10-second sprinter in the 100-yard dash."It was amazing a man that big could run that fast," Crane said.To almost nobody's surprise, Blanchard became the first junior to win the Heisman Trophy and the first football player to win the Sullivan Award, given to the country's top college athlete.Blanchard's bid to win back-to-back Heismans ended when he tore knee ligaments in the 1946 opener against Villanova.He missed only two games and played the rest of the season at about 60%, according to Blaik.Blanchard still ran for 613 yards and 10 touchdowns, and finished fifth in the Heisman voting, with Davis capturing the trophy."We tried to complement each other and really weren't competing," Blanchard said soon before his death at age 84. "You've just got to be the right kind of people with the right kind of interests. If you're interested in the welfare of the team, you don't have that problem."Man In BlueIn 1947 he graduated from West Point and was commissioned as a second lieutenant in the brand-new Air Force. He married Joy King — they had three children — then embarked on a career as a fighter pilot.He was inducted into the College Football Hall of Fame in 1959.Said Crane: "He had a remarkable life."
