Jonas Salk stopped polio cold with the first effective vaccine. In 1954, cases numbered 38,968 and the public feared the paralyzing disease more than anything except nuclear war.
Then came the exciting announcement on April 12, 1955.
The Salk vaccine had been used in the largest medical experiment in history and had been proved to prevent polio.
The quiet researcher became a huge figure overnight, and that made colleagues jealous.
They refused to accept that his approach, using a killed virus given by shots, would provide long-term immunity.
After 1962, the Sabin oral vaccine, using a live virus, became the preferred method until it was recalled due to risks in 1999.

"The prevention of poliomyelitis remains Salk's greatest achievement," Charlotte Jacobs, author of "Jonas Salk: A Life," told IBD. "In the long run, many of his ideas about vaccination were adopted, but during his lifetime he had to be very determined and persistent to achieve his goals against so much resistance to innovation."
New York Rise
Salk (1914-95) was born into a Jewish family in East Harlem, N.Y.
Two years later, 7,000 Americans died of poliomyelitis, which caused paralysis in many survivors. This epidemic was overlooked because of the hundreds of thousands dying in World War I.
On top of that, 20 million died worldwide from influenza in 1918, and the polio threat was forgotten.

Salk skipped grades and entered the City College of New York at 15, graduating with a degree in chemistry in 1934. He then enrolled in medical school at New York University, but with no intention of becoming a doctor.
He wanted to be a medical researcher, inspired to help mankind after reading about French chemist Louis Pasteur, who developed vaccines for rabies and anthrax.
After Salk's freshman year, he took off for a year to do research and teach biochemistry, then returned to classes and clinical rotations.
In 1936, his first paper was published in a medical journal, he graduated and he married Donna Lindsay.

Their three sons would receive medical degrees and help their father in research. However, preoccupation with his work resulted in a divorce in 1968, and two years later he married artist Francoise Gilot.

As his residency at Mount Sinai Hospital in New York was ending in 1941, Salk applied to do research on viruses at the University of Michigan under renowned virologist Thomas Francis. As World War II raged, Francis got Salk an exemption from the draft in 1942 for critical medical research.
The duo developed a killed-virus vaccine against strains of flu. That meant it would stimulate the body's immune reaction without being as dangerous as a live virus.

Few scientists believed it would confer long-term immunity, but then came stronger proof: Some 12,500 soldiers were given a test inoculation in late 1943, and it was so successful that two years later the Army mandated vaccinations for 8 million GIs. This reduced the rate of flu infection by 92% compared with the civilian population.
By 30, Salk had proved that the killed virus provided long-term immunity from the flu.

But he found that scientific arguments were not enough to convince skeptics among leading virologists. They resisted his method of increasing vaccine effectiveness by adding adjuvants — chemical agents that allowed using smaller doses of the virus, which would eventually become accepted.

"Despite the attacks on his reputation by others in the field, which would only increase throughout his career, he never struck back in anger and, at least in public, remained calm, a trait that would win admirers among the small group of scientists who supported his innovations," said Jacobs. "He was politely tenacious and believed that, in the end, he only had to answer to himself."

In 1947, two years after the war ended, Salk became director of the virus lab at the University of Pittsburgh, with more than a 50% salary increase to $7,500 (the equivalent of $80,000 now). But he soon found that his freedom to research what he wanted was restricted and he lacked adequate funding.

Then Harry Weaver visited. He was the head of research for the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, founded in 1938 by President Franklin D. Roosevelt, the world's most famous polio victim, and later renamed the March of Dimes after its fundraising efforts.

"In 1939, a comparatively modest 7,343 people in the U.S. had contracted polio," wrote Jeffrey Kluger in "Splendid Solution: Jonas Salk and the Conquest of Polio." "In 1946, a staggering 25,698 Americans had been sickened by polio, nearly double the 1945 total and the most in 26 years. No part of the country was spared."

Salk agreed to work for the NFIP on the monotonous task of determining what the different polio viruses were. Funds from Weaver's foundation began to flow to the lab, letting him hire other researchers.
Help On The Way
A key moment came in September 1951, when Salk presented their findings at an international conference. He predicted a vaccine would be available in five years.

"There was nobody like him in those days," Weaver recalled. "He thought big. ... He was out of phase with the tradition of narrowing research down to one or two details, making progress inch by inch. He wanted to leap, not crawl."

Salk mobilized a veritable army, rolling out a field trial of his vaccine in 1954-55 involving 20,000 physicians and public health officers, 40,000 nurses, 64,000 school staff, 220,000 volunteers and 1.8 million children.
The result inspired the country.
Salk had many offers for a movie made about his life after the April 1955 unveiling, which showed that the unvaccinated, who had been given a placebo, were 3.3 times likelier to contract polio.
But a few weeks later, some officials blamed the vaccine for causing polio in some areas. It turned out that one of the manufacturers had a flawed process, but it gave critics ammo to discredit Salk.

Regardless, the Salk vaccine worked. By the summer of 1957, 100 million doses had been distributed throughout America, out of a population of 179 million. Polio cases plummeted to 6,000 by the end of the year, and other countries were also getting healthier.

Meanwhile, Dr. Albert Sabin developed an oral vaccine using a live virus. That was adopted by the Soviet Union and a few other countries and did a number on polio with the first 4.5 million patients by 1959.
More Avenues
By 1962, the cheaper cost and easier use of the oral version had made it more popular in the U.S., too.

"Salk brought the polio caseload down to 1,000, and it took Sabin to carry the baton the rest of the way," wrote Kluger. "Or so it seemed. The Salk vaccine had only been in use for seven years before Sabin's was introduced and was on a glide path. ... (But) the biggest misgiving about the live formulation (that it risked causing polio) appeared to be well-founded."

Salk decided to think bigger. In 1962 he opened the Salk Institute for Biological Studies in La Jolla, Calif., rallying top researchers to see what would result from the collaboration. Among them were five who received or would land the Nobel Prize, including the co-discoverer of DNA, Francis Crick, and leading nuclear physicist Leo Szilard.
Salk started projects to find cures for cancer, multiple sclerosis and influenza, but wasn't able to raise sufficient funds to finish them.
He also found that he wasn't a solid manager of day-to-day operations, preferring to cede control while he did research. Financial problems led to his ouster in 1984.
His attention was soon captured by the epidemic of AIDS, which by the end of 1985 had been contracted by 23,000 Americans, 11,000 of whom had died.

One of the world's top AIDS researchers, American Robert Gallo, visited Salk to seek his advice. Salk found himself mediating a dispute between Gallo and Frenchman Luc Montagnier over who had discovered the AIDS virus.

In April 1987, after two years of negotiation, President Reagan and French Prime Minister Jacques Chirac announced that Gallo and Montagnier would be recognized as co-discoverers, with joint ownership of the blood-test patent.
Eight years later, Salk died at 80.

In 2014, Robert Redford, who had a mild case of polio as a child, released a documentary on the Salk Institute, still a premier medical and scientific research center.Jonas Salk stopped polio cold with the first effective vaccine. In 1954, cases numbered 38,968 and the public feared the paralyzing disease more than anything except nuclear war.Then came the exciting announcement on April 12, 1955.The Salk vaccine had been used in the largest medical experiment in history and had been proved to prevent polio.The quiet researcher became a huge figure overnight, and that made colleagues jealous.They refused to accept that his approach, using a killed virus given by shots, would provide long-term immunity.After 1962, the Sabin oral vaccine, using a live virus, became the preferred method until it was recalled due to risks in 1999."The prevention of poliomyelitis remains Salk's greatest achievement," Charlotte Jacobs, author of "Jonas Salk: A Life," told IBD. "In the long run, many of his ideas about vaccination were adopted, but during his lifetime he had to be very determined and persistent to achieve his goals against so much resistance to innovation."New York RiseSalk (1914-95) was born into a Jewish family in East Harlem, N.Y.Two years later, 7,000 Americans died of poliomyelitis, which caused paralysis in many survivors. This epidemic was overlooked because of the hundreds of thousands dying in World War I.On top of that, 20 million died worldwide from influenza in 1918, and the polio threat was forgotten.Salk skipped grades and entered the City College of New York at 15, graduating with a degree in chemistry in 1934. He then enrolled in medical school at New York University, but with no intention of becoming a doctor.He wanted to be a medical researcher, inspired to help mankind after reading about French chemist Louis Pasteur, who developed vaccines for rabies and anthrax.After Salk's freshman year, he took off for a year to do research and teach biochemistry, then returned to classes and clinical rotations.In 1936, his first paper was published in a medical journal, he graduated and he married Donna Lindsay.Their three sons would receive medical degrees and help their father in research. However, preoccupation with his work resulted in a divorce in 1968, and two years later he married artist Francoise Gilot.As his residency at Mount Sinai Hospital in New York was ending in 1941, Salk applied to do research on viruses at the University of Michigan under renowned virologist Thomas Francis. As World War II raged, Francis got Salk an exemption from the draft in 1942 for critical medical research.The duo developed a killed-virus vaccine against strains of flu. That meant it would stimulate the body's immune reaction without being as dangerous as a live virus.Few scientists believed it would confer long-term immunity, but then came stronger proof: Some 12,500 soldiers were given a test inoculation in late 1943, and it was so successful that two years later the Army mandated vaccinations for 8 million GIs. This reduced the rate of flu infection by 92% compared with the civilian population.By 30, Salk had proved that the killed virus provided long-term immunity from the flu.But he found that scientific arguments were not enough to convince skeptics among leading virologists. They resisted his method of increasing vaccine effectiveness by adding adjuvants — chemical agents that allowed using smaller doses of the virus, which would eventually become accepted."Despite the attacks on his reputation by others in the field, which would only increase throughout his career, he never struck back in anger and, at least in public, remained calm, a trait that would win admirers among the small group of scientists who supported his innovations," said Jacobs. "He was politely tenacious and believed that, in the end, he only had to answer to himself."In 1947, two years after the war ended, Salk became director of the virus lab at the University of Pittsburgh, with more than a 50% salary increase to $7,500 (the equivalent of $80,000 now). But he soon found that his freedom to research what he wanted was restricted and he lacked adequate funding.Then Harry Weaver visited. He was the head of research for the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, founded in 1938 by President Franklin D. Roosevelt, the world's most famous polio victim, and later renamed the March of Dimes after its fundraising efforts."In 1939, a comparatively modest 7,343 people in the U.S. had contracted polio," wrote Jeffrey Kluger in "Splendid Solution: Jonas Salk and the Conquest of Polio." "In 1946, a staggering 25,698 Americans had been sickened by polio, nearly double the 1945 total and the most in 26 years. No part of the country was spared."Salk agreed to work for the NFIP on the monotonous task of determining what the different polio viruses were. Funds from Weaver's foundation began to flow to the lab, letting him hire other researchers.Help On The WayA key moment came in September 1951, when Salk presented their findings at an international conference. He predicted a vaccine would be available in five years."There was nobody like him in those days," Weaver recalled. "He thought big. ... He was out of phase with the tradition of narrowing research down to one or two details, making progress inch by inch. He wanted to leap, not crawl."Salk mobilized a veritable army, rolling out a field trial of his vaccine in 1954-55 involving 20,000 physicians and public health officers, 40,000 nurses, 64,000 school staff, 220,000 volunteers and 1.8 million children.The result inspired the country.Salk had many offers for a movie made about his life after the April 1955 unveiling, which showed that the unvaccinated, who had been given a placebo, were 3.3 times likelier to contract polio.But a few weeks later, some officials blamed the vaccine for causing polio in some areas. It turned out that one of the manufacturers had a flawed process, but it gave critics ammo to discredit Salk.Regardless, the Salk vaccine worked. By the summer of 1957, 100 million doses had been distributed throughout America, out of a population of 179 million. Polio cases plummeted to 6,000 by the end of the year, and other countries were also getting healthier.Meanwhile, Dr. Albert Sabin developed an oral vaccine using a live virus. That was adopted by the Soviet Union and a few other countries and did a number on polio with the first 4.5 million patients by 1959.More AvenuesBy 1962, the cheaper cost and easier use of the oral version had made it more popular in the U.S., too."Salk brought the polio caseload down to 1,000, and it took Sabin to carry the baton the rest of the way," wrote Kluger. "Or so it seemed. The Salk vaccine had only been in use for seven years before Sabin's was introduced and was on a glide path. ... (But) the biggest misgiving about the live formulation (that it risked causing polio) appeared to be well-founded."Salk decided to think bigger. In 1962 he opened the Salk Institute for Biological Studies in La Jolla, Calif., rallying top researchers to see what would result from the collaboration. Among them were five who received or would land the Nobel Prize, including the co-discoverer of DNA, Francis Crick, and leading nuclear physicist Leo Szilard.Salk started projects to find cures for cancer, multiple sclerosis and influenza, but wasn't able to raise sufficient funds to finish them.He also found that he wasn't a solid manager of day-to-day operations, preferring to cede control while he did research. Financial problems led to his ouster in 1984.His attention was soon captured by the epidemic of AIDS, which by the end of 1985 had been contracted by 23,000 Americans, 11,000 of whom had died.One of the world's top AIDS researchers, American Robert Gallo, visited Salk to seek his advice. Salk found himself mediating a dispute between Gallo and Frenchman Luc Montagnier over who had discovered the AIDS virus.In April 1987, after two years of negotiation, President Reagan and French Prime Minister Jacques Chirac announced that Gallo and Montagnier would be recognized as co-discoverers, with joint ownership of the blood-test patent.Eight years later, Salk died at 80.In 2014, Robert Redford, who had a mild case of polio as a child, released a documentary on the Salk Institute, still a premier medical and scientific research center.

Yum Brands' Taco Bell (YUM) hops on the protein-packed bandwagon next week with the nationwide debut of its "Cantina Power" menu, a meaty offering aimed at reeling in health-conscious consumers looking to limit carbs. The menu's burritos and bowls boasting twice the chicken or steak will have more than 20 grams of protein and fewer than 500 calories each. Those…

General Mills (GIS) said Thursday that quarterly revenue fell more than expected as consumers continued to shy away from processed cold cereals and trend toward natural foods, and it vowed to expand restructuring efforts to further cut costs and lift sales. General Mills stock has been consolidating since early August, trading in a narrow range. But shares closed down 3.3%…

How does a high-quality stock with a big dividend yield top itself? One way is for the company to increase the cash payout itself. Here are five stocks with yields of 3% or better and a double-digit dividend growth rate — how fast a stock's dividend rises over three to five years, as calculated by IBD. Cisco Systems (CSCO) pays…

A stock that plays good defense isn't expected to outperform the S&P; 500. Yet consider the performance of packaged-food giant General Mills (GIS) on defense and offense. During the bear market of 2007-09, the S&P; 500 plunged 58%. General Mills lost 21%. During the bear market of 2000-02, the S&P; 500 careened 50.5% lower. Meanwhile, General Mills rose 9%. How's…

Hormel and Campbell Soup earnings reports on Tuesday left investors rubbing their bellies, even though sales were less appetizing. Cost-cutting explains why profits rose despite falling sales. Campbell Soup (CPB), whose products include Goldfish crackers and Pepperidge Farms cookies in addition to its trademark soups, said in July that it planned on $250 million in annual cost savings by the…

Kraft Heinz (KHC) on Wednesday said it would terminate roughly 2,600 jobs through the closure of seven North American factories, a move that comes as large food and consumer-products makers try to cut costs and rid themselves of underperforming brands. Kraft Heinz hopes to use the savings to upgrade its plants. Operations from the shuttered plants will move to other…

General Mills (GIS) has increased its dividend six times in the past five years as the packaged-food giant adapts to a growing market for healthier foods.The latest increase took effect early this month, when the Minneapolis, Minn.-based company boosted its quarterly payout by 3 cents, or 7%, to 44 cents per share.The long-term dividend growth rate is 11%, among the highest in IBD's Dividend Leaders screen. The annualized payout of $1.76 a share yields 3% at the current share price, well above the S&P 500 average of 1.9%.The maker of products under brands such as Cheerios, Pillsbury and Betty Crocker boasts that it has paid a dividend for 116 straight years.The stock is getting support at its 50-day line as it works on a flat base with a possible 57.83 buy point.General Mills appears to be having success in trimming costs and broadening its product line to meet rising demand for natural and organic products.But in a setback, earlier this year Target (TGT) reportedly told General Mills and other suppliers that it would reduce the amount of money and effort it devotes to promoting products such as canned soup and packaged cereals.General Mills has responded to changes in tastes with its 2012 purchase of Yoplait yogurt and the purchase last year of organic food maker Annie's Homegrown. It also plans to introduce gluten-free Cheerios early next year.Like many big-cap stocks, General Mills' sales and profit growth has been slow but steady. The three-year annual profit growth rate is 3%. Sales over that span have also grown at a 3% pace.General Mills earlier this month reiterated that sales and profit will grow at a low single-digit pace in the fiscal year ending in May.

Campbell Soup (CPB) shares warmed up on Friday after the food company topped fiscal third-quarter earnings estimates and gave slightly optimistic full-year guidance despite currency headwinds.Earnings came in flat at 62 cents a share in Q3, above a Thomson Reuters analyst poll by 10 cents. Campbell, like other food giants, continued cost-cutting efforts and curbed promotions. Gross margin rose to 35.9% from 34.3% a year earlier.Revenue fell 3.6% to $1.9 billion, just below expectations for $1.93 billion, due to currency fluctuations and the impact of retailer inventory movements on its U.S. soup business, the company said. It was the second straight year-over-year sales decline and the worst drop in nearly three years.For the full year, Campbell expects revenue to fall closer to the lower end of its prior guidance for -1% to 1%. Analysts have calculated sales to drop 1.7%.Campbell sees full-year earnings closer to the favorable end of its range of $2.32-$2.38 a share, while Wall St. has estimated $2.35 vs. last year's $2.53.Shares climbed 1.8% to 47.78 in the stock market today intraday. Shares are nearing a 48.40 buy point from a flat base.Campbell has an IBD Composite Rating of 55 out of 99, meaning its shares outperform 55% of all stocks in the market as measured by fundamental and technical factors. Some of those factors are earnings and sales growth, return on equity, profit margins and relative price performance.WhiteWave Foods (WWAV), which was spun off from Dean Foods (DF) in 2012, leads the Food-Packaged industry group with a 93 Composite Rating. Earlier this month, WhiteWave, the maker of Silk nondairy milk and Earthbound Farms salads, reported Q1 earnings that topped views and sales that met views.WhiteWave's results were also affected by the strong dollar. Revenue from Europe would have risen 23% on a currency-adjusted basis, but rose just 4% on a reported basis.Still, WhiteWave raised its full-year earnings guidance.Natural and organic foods companyHain Celestial (HAIN) also raised its full-year guidance and sales outlook after issuing Q1 results earlier this month. Hain's earnings matched forecasts, while sales slightly topped views.Hain holds the No. 2 spot in the Food-Packaged group with a 90 Composite Rating.Other companies in the group include Kraft Foods (KRFT), Pinnacle Foods (PF), Conagra Foods (CAG), General Mills (GIS) and Kellogg (K).Follow Alissa Williams on Twitter: @IBD_AWilliams.
At 93, Ed Shames is the last living officer of Easy Company, the "Band of Brothers" immortalized by the 2001 HBO TV series about World War II.
Serving initially in the Army's Item Company, 3rd Battalion, 506th Parachute Infantry Regiment, 101st Airborne Division, he was dropped behind enemy lines on D-Day, June 6, 1944.
Over the next week, they fought fierce Nazi resistance around Carentan, a rail center between the Americans coming in from Utah Beach and those who landed at Omaha Beach.
Victory came on June 13, his 22nd birthday, and he was given the battalion's first battlefield promotion, to second lieutenant.
"If we'd lost, the Germans would have probably pushed us back into the sea," Shames told IBD from Virginia Beach, Va., his home with Ida, his wife of 69 years.

Ian Gardner, author of "Airborne: The Combat Story of Ed Shames of Easy Company," wrote: "Carentan was where Ed's fighting reputation was established, and from the 101st Airborne perspective it was one of the most important and decisive engagements of its entire Normandy campaign."
Aiming Straight

Shames was born into an Orthodox Jewish family in Virginia Beach in 1922. His father and mother owned a grocery store, but Dad died when Ed was 5. Left with a Smith & Wesson pistol, Ed became a crack shot in the woods.
At 19, he was attending the Steam Engineering School in Norfolk, hoping to become a naval engineer, when the Japanese hit Pearl Harbor on Dec. 7, 1941.
Reading in the paper about a new volunteer force in the Army's experiment with parachuting infantry, he joined and began training at Camp Toccoa, Ga.
The 506th PIR arrived in England in September 1943 for further preparation, and Shames became the operations sergeant for the 3rd Battalion's commander, Col. Lee Wolverton.
On June 5, 1944, at 11:30 p.m., the air armada took off for Normandy ahead of the invasion.
The cloud cover required the Allied planes to stay low and slow, resulting in many being shot down.
In the chaos of landing, Shames learned from other paratroops that Wolverton and much of I Company had died in two crashes, so he was attached to H Company.

"German Field Marshal Erwin Rommel had ordered Carentan defended 'to the last man,'" wrote Stephen Ambrose in "Band of Brothers." "The country around it was full of very dense hedges at least 6 feet tall on either side of narrow lanes. This was about as bad a place to launch an infantry assault as could be imagined, as bad as clearing out a town house by house, as bad as attacking a World War I trench system.
"Little progress could be made toward Cherbourg, the largest port in Normandy and a major strategic objective, until the bottleneck at Carentan had been broken."

After initial fighting and heavy Allied bombing of the town, Shames' 3rd Battalion moved in from the north on June 13 through hedged fields. His H Company came under heavy fire when he realized F Company was not on the right to protect the flank, having been driven back. After close calls, he made it to regimental headquarters to alert the brass. "Without a doubt, his quick thinking helped to change the outcome of the battle," wrote Gardner.
Fighting for H Company occurred on a sunken road — Bloody Gully — then 502nd PIR tanks rolled to the rescue. A bullet had taken out a piece of Shames' nose, but he taped it up and fought on.

Carentan was the last battle in Normandy. The 506th PIR had taken 983 casualties, 50% of the total of all regiments in the campaign, with the 3rd Battalion the hardest hit. The GIs were sent to England for recuperation and training, with Shames reassigned to the 2nd Battalion as an intelligence officer.

On Sept. 17, Shames and the 506th PIR landed near Eindhoven, Holland, as part of Operation Market Garden, involving 40,000 other U.S. and British paratroopers. Allied commanders thought the enemy would collapse, opening the way into northern Germany.
Instead, the Nazis regrouped and counterattacked, making it daunting for the Allies to hold the bridges and roads essential to moving men through a marshy country covered by rivers and dikes.
Shames spent much of his time working with the Dutch underground on reconnaissance missions. The Allies began withdrawing eight days after the drop, having suffered 17,000 casualties.

On Oct. 2, the 506th PIR trekked toward "the Island," an area below sea level with 7-foot dikes near Arnhem. After artillery duels and assaults, the front line settled into a stalemate while Shames, shot in the left leg, went to the hospital.

In a few days he took over the 40-man 3rd Platoon of Easy Company. "We all had nicknames and mine was SOB — Son of the Battalion — because I was tough," said Shames. "I was a perfectionist and never satisfied."
Easy Does It
He and Easy Company now had new orders: Help rescue a stranded group of 149 British troops, Dutch fighters and Americans.
On the night of Oct. 22-23, Operation Pegasus managed to evacuate all of them to the Allied side of a river without casualties.

Hitler launched his last great offensive on the Western Front on Dec. 16, through the heavily forested Ardennes region of Belgium, Luxembourg and France. It caught the Allies by surprise and became known as the Battle of the Bulge.
Initially, the Germans had more men and were better equipped.
On Dec. 18, the 101st Airborne rumbled by truck to Bastogne, Belgium, a key crossroads.
Shames and his fellow soldiers were surrounded in the bitter cold without adequate clothing, food or ammo to counter the Nazi attacks.
"Our patrolling let the enemy know that despite the situation, we were still on the offensive and I made sure my men constantly honed their skills," said Shames.

The siege was broken on Dec. 26, and by then the men of the 101st were a legend back home for their heroic defense. But the fighting continued in woods near Foy, which the 2nd and 3rd Battalions captured on Jan. 13, 1945, then cleared the enemy out of two other towns over the next few days.
Shames took shrapnel in his left knee and would receive a third Purple Heart, as well as promotion to first lieutenant.

The Battle of the Bulge ended on Jan. 25, turning out to be the largest fought by the U.S. in the war, with the 610,000 Americans suffering 89,000 casualties (55,000 Brits took 2,500). The 550,000 German soldiers involved lost 100,000.
Coming Through
"Of the 500 platoons in the 101st, 3rd Platoon brought more men home than any other, so the hard training was worth it," said Shames.
On April 3, the 506th PIR moved to Duesseldorf on the Rhine River. Soon, 325,000 Germans gave up.
The 506th then rode by train to southern Germany to stabilize the area as the 7th Army pushed back the last resistance.
Slave labor camps were discovered that had been producing fighters and bombers.
On April 28, Shames was with a humanitarian mission to one camp that had been run by the Nazis and found 100 prisoners suffering from typhus and malnutrition.

On May 2 he visited Dachau, which had just been liberated. The Nazi death camp had slaughtered 28,000, mostly Jews, with piles of bodies unburied. "The stench and horror will be with me as long as I live," said Shames.
On May 5, a cease-fire was in place and the 101st Airborne was ordered to take control of Hitler's Alpine retreat at Berchtesgaden.
Shames liberated a bottle of cognac with the Fuehrer's initials, but didn't drink it for 20 years.

Victory in Europe Day came on May 8. Two days later, while Shames was directing roadblocks to capture Nazi leaders, a car with Field Marshal Albert Kesselring was halted. He refused to surrender his pistol to anyone less than a major until Shames put a .45 to his head.
Shames arrived back in Norfolk in September. He married Ida Aframe in January 1946, settled in Virginia Beach, and their two sons would join the Army.

As to what he did after the war, Gardner wrote, "Ed was subsequently recalled to service and much of what he did is still classified, but he and sometimes Ida were allowed to travel the world and experience different cultures."

Shames says he can't elaborate, but said, "I've had an amazing life."At 93, Ed Shames is the last living officer of Easy Company, the "Band of Brothers" immortalized by the 2001 HBO TV series about World War II.Serving initially in the Army's Item Company, 3rd Battalion, 506th Parachute Infantry Regiment, 101st Airborne Division, he was dropped behind enemy lines on D-Day, June 6, 1944.Over the next week, they fought fierce Nazi resistance around Carentan, a rail center between the Americans coming in from Utah Beach and those who landed at Omaha Beach.Victory came on June 13, his 22nd birthday, and he was given the battalion's first battlefield promotion, to second lieutenant."If we'd lost, the Germans would have probably pushed us back into the sea," Shames told IBD from Virginia Beach, Va., his home with Ida, his wife of 69 years.Ian Gardner, author of "Airborne: The Combat Story of Ed Shames of Easy Company," wrote: "Carentan was where Ed's fighting reputation was established, and from the 101st Airborne perspective it was one of the most important and decisive engagements of its entire Normandy campaign."Aiming StraightShames was born into an Orthodox Jewish family in Virginia Beach in 1922. This was about as bad a place to launch an infantry assault as could be imagined, as bad as clearing out a town house by house, as bad as attacking a World War I trench system."Little progress could be made toward Cherbourg, the largest port in Normandy and a major strategic objective, until the bottleneck at Carentan had been broken."After initial fighting and heavy Allied bombing of the town, Shames' 3rd Battalion moved in from the north on June 13 through hedged fields. Dave Thomas had a simple goal as he grew up: own a restaurant. He exceeded that by a multiple of 6,000, building that many Wendy's eateries in 30 years of operation."When Wendy's began in 1969, I saw the chance to have perhaps three or four restaurants in the Columbus, Ohio, area," he wrote. "When we built those and they worked, the company grew, and more opportunities opened up. Opportunity never knocked, but it was all around us. You just had to see it."The empire that Thomas built led to a Wendy's (WEN) stock that's still hot, rising 300% since 2008.Rex David Thomas (1932-2002) formed his vision of Wendy's early."In 1940, at the age of 8, I dreamed I would one day own the best restaurant in the world," he wrote in his 1992 book, "Dave's Way." "All of the customers would love my food, and all of my employees would do everything they were supposed to do. But, most important, everyone would think I was a good boss, and every day when I walked into the restaurant, people would be glad to see me."Cooking Up A CourseWhen he was in 10th grade, he wrote an essay on "The Pursuit of Happiness," noting:"After I finish school, I want to join the Army for a while and be a cook. In this way, I will get more experience. I will have my education and my Army experience. I will be all set to start the pursuit of happiness with a restaurant of my own."Dave didn't finish high school in Fort Wayne, Ind. Aside from that, he said, "I achieved it all. My plan wasn't fancy, but it was all I needed."His rise wasn't easy. He never knew his birth mother. His adoptive mother died when he was 5."Her name was Auleva, and she died of rheumatic fever," Dave wrote. "I really don't remember her, what she looked like or how she treated me. But I do remember she was very sick, and when she died it scared me to be around so many people because I wasn't used to strangers. We never had any visitors at our house, and I wasn't sure how I was supposed to act."His adoptive dad, Rex, "was a hard worker, and honest," he wrote. "But as far as being a father, he didn't have the time or the inclination."Despite moving often, Dave didn't lack for guardian angels. His adoptive mother's mom was his earliest champion. "When my (adoptive) mother's casket was lowered into the ground, it bothered me a lot," he wrote. "My adoptive grandmother, Minnie Sinclair, explained my mother had gone to heaven where she would watch over me."While in grade school, Dave spent summers on Minnie's Michigan farm. "She was born and raised in the hills of Kentucky," Dave wrote. "She had so little, but she made so much out of it. She believed that if you worked hard, you made things happen."Minnie raised four children by herself after her husband was killed in a railroad work accident. "I took whatever work I could find after Grandpa died," she told Dave. "I knew the Lord would provide. All of my children grew up to be fine people."Minnie had a strong sense of fun, making shopping and eating out an adventure. She was also tough. "She taught me you could be strict but show you cared at the same time," noted Thomas. "Minnie was a motivator. If you did the right thing, she could make you feel 10 feet tall and very, very special."Minnie taught Dave not to cut corners — a hallmark of Wendy's, with its top-of-the-line square burgers."Quality's everything," she told him. "Remember that. If people keep cutting corners, this country's going to be in big trouble."With this firm foundation, Dave took solid principles to his professional life. At 12, he dived into the food arena, delivering groceries.He gained early experience in his chosen restaurant field, always building on what he learned. By 15, he was ready for business, staying behind in Fort Wayne to work at the Hobby House restaurant while his family moved away."What I did is not something I'd recommend to any kid today," he wrote. "I was ... working 50 hours a week, minimum, still in Fort Wayne Central High School and living at the Y. It wasn't much longer until I quit school. My real vocation was the restaurant business."Phil Clauss, the Hobby House owner, was the next crucial Dave mentor. "He was a hard worker and an innovator who believed in progress and change," Thomas wrote. "His personal instinct for taking care of the customer was so strong. Whatever he did got attention. If he was doing pancakes, he was the best pancake maker you ever met. Phil was also the kind of guy who said, 'If I can do it, anyone can do it.' I used to try to match hour to hour with him."Army And KFCWhile working at Hobby House, Thomas enlisted as a cook in the Army. The work at his base in Germany from 1950 to 1953 bored him, and he yearned to be an entrepreneur. His roommate managed the enlisted men's club, and the two brainstormed ways to improve the establishment's food. When Dave's suggestions were hits with the GIs, his roommate tagged him for an assistant manager spot.In the early 1960s, Thomas and Clauss shifted into higher gear by investing in Harlan Sanders' Kentucky Fried Chicken.Thomas also worked as a regional manager for KFC. Then, after leaving the chicken chain in the late 1960s, he invested in a firm called National Diversified, a restaurant holding company that asked him to turn around a losing unit, Arthur Treacher's Fish & Chips, which he did. Such experience sparked his interest in starting his own outfit.Thomas "was never satisfied with the status quo," Michael Seid, a franchising consultant who was Dave's co-author in "Franchising for Dummies," told IBD. "Innovations that were introduced at Wendy's have changed the way the quick-service restaurant industry functions today. For example, the single line at Wendy's is called a snake. Dave invented it, and other restaurant chains copied it."While with KFC, Thomas and Clauss boosted marketing operations, developing the meal in a bucket and unique signage: lighting up the bucket on a pole. "Dave created his initial nest egg as a franchisee of Kentucky Fried Chicken," said Seid. "He even wore the white suit like Colonel Sanders."Upbeat OutlookThomas knew that eateries were a people business. "You can tell if a restaurant is excited about having customers come in," he wrote. "You can also read the enthusiasm on the customers' faces. A restaurant team that is upbeat and disciplined has a real effect on customers."When Thomas got out of the Army, he went back to work for Clauss — as a manager and the go-to problem solver.Thomas "was a serial entrepreneur before he began Wendy's," said Seid. "He had a lifetime of achievements before he was 35."By the mid-1960s, Thomas was in charge of an underperforming group of Clauss' KFC units. He turned them around, then sold his stake to Sanders for $1.5 million.Thomas' heart, soul and stomach were in Wendy's — named for his daughter. His ardor partly explains why he was its public face and voice for years. Dave starred in the company's TV commercials in the 1980s and 1990s."The genius of Wendy's inserting Dave Thomas, its founder, into its advertising was that Dave was a man of virtue and integrity," said Geoffrey Precourt, an editor at Warc, an advertising, marketing and media news service. "He's a guy who could be your next door neighbor or the stranger who offers to help you carry your groceries to your car. He's so likable — and even before there were online Likes, favorability was critical to building brand loyalty.... When television became the focal point of households, personality became an integral part of branding. Just as Clara Peller humorously reminded us that Wendy's had a meatier product (with her 'Where's the beef?' line), so did Dave Thomas give us the notion that fast food could be comfort food. ... (Dave was) one of those CEOs like (Chrysler's) Lee Iacocca or (chicken man) Frank Perdue who could carry a brand."Dave never forgot his roots. In 1990, President George H.W. Bush urge him to put his marketing skills behind a national adoption effort.From that came the Dave Thomas Foundation for Adoption to help children find a permanent family.And that high school diploma? Thomas landed it in 1993, then founded the Dave Thomas Education Center in Coconut Creek, Fla., to hike GED skills.

In 1968, Mark Spitz promised his fans that he would bring home no fewer than six gold medals from the Mexico City Olympics. Instead, the swashbuckling swimmer took silver in the 100-meter butterfly, bronze in the 100-meter freestyle and two gold medals in his team relay events.Meanwhile, he came in last in the 200-meter butterfly and didn't win any solo race.His take? He could do better."I considered myself a failure," Spitz, now 65, told IBD from his home in Los Angeles.Still, he knew that worrying about drowned dreams was a waste of time. So he focused his goggles on 1972 and the Munich Games.Making a serious splash in Germany, Mark the Shark sliced through the water with unstoppable force.The 22-year-old's first contest: The 200-meter butterfly, the same race that choked him in '68."He didn't just win," wrote biographer Richard Foster. "He demolished the field and the record."The Shiny SevenOver the next few days, Spitz latched onto more golds: in the 200-meter freestyle, 100-meter butterfly and 100-meter freestyle.He also swam in relay events for three more golds.With those seven medals, he was the most victorious Olympian at a single venue, passing the record of five held by previous athletes.Spitz held his distinction for 36 years, until fellow American Michael Phelps swam to eight gold medals at the 2008 Beijing Games.The poster of 6-foot-tall Spitz wearing all seven of those medals, beaming with his moustache, sinewy torso, and stars and stripes swimsuit, sold a million copies — and he got a decent cut of the sales.He was on course as a founding father of athletic endorsement. He's pitched Bausch & Lomb, General Motors (GM), General Mills (GIS) and other brands, most recently the tour company Windstar Cruises.He's worth about $20 million, according to ForbesNetWorth.com."As it's happening, you have no clue you are pioneering anything," he said. "You are out there, relentlessly taking risks and trying to expand, capturing success either from the training that you have had or the tenacity that you are gaining."Sports Illustrated named Spitz Athlete of the 20th Century in water sports, reflecting what dominated the Munich scene — until the slaughter. Just hours after he won his seventh gold, Palestinian terrorists kidnapped and murdered 11 Israeli Olympic team members.The Munich Massacre still haunts him. "It was a terrible tragedy," he said.Terrifying, too. As a Jew, he was smuggled out of the Olympic village in a blanket for his safety. Though the Games continued, he wasn't around for the closing ceremonies.Spitz traveled to Israel a couple of years later to meet with the families of the fallen athletes and coaches. They talked about the spirit of the Olympics.With its emphasis on hard work, self-discipline and the champion's mindset, they agreed, the Games trump the evils of terrorism.Spitz was born in 1950 in Modesto, Calif., the oldest of three children to Arnold Spitz, a World War II gunner and scrap metal expert, and his wife, Lenore, a homemaker. Arnold was intense. Lenore was practical and charming. Both put family at the center of their midcentury lives.Mark was 2 when Arnold moved the family to Honolulu.Lenore later recalled that little Mark ran headlong toward the ocean the first time he saw it, as if he sensed his Aquaman destiny.The Spitzes had two more kids, Heidi and Nancy, in Hawaii before they moved back to California when Mark was 6.That summer, Lenore took the kids to the Sacramento YMCA to keep them occupied. Soon enough, Mark was on the Y swim team.Fatherly AdviceSpitz had what it took: long arms, scooping hands and well-balanced legs. He also had a powerful cheering squad. From the time he was a tadpole, Dad made it clear:Victory, or go home."Swimming isn't everything," he told young Mark. "Winning is."That chutzpah propelled Mark to wake at dawn six days a week, 11 months a year, churning mile upon mile in chilly water.Out of the pool, he scarfed food to replace the calories he burned.Those who saw the Kid Wonder knew he was something spectacular. "He almost lifted himself out of the pool to pass his opponents," coach Sherm Chavoor later wrote in "The 50-Meter Jungle." "He has had the ability to do that all his life. It's a natural, inborn talent to extend himself beyond all physical endurance when the time comes. When I saw him do it in that obscure little meet for little kids back in 1960, there was no longer any doubt in my mind. I knew even then that I had a great one."Chavoor became Spitz's longtime mentor when the boy was 9.When Spitz was 14, he went up the coast to train with coach George Haines in Santa Clara, but Chavoor stayed close.Today, Spitz believes that practice and a stellar mental attitude are more important than talent when it comes to reaching the top.Work hard early in your career, he advises, and you'll stand out."People who are successful have a real wide base," he said. "Most people build a base like an inverted pyramid. They've got a tiny starting point the size of a dollar bill. And they are expecting, when they get to the top, an acre of knowledge. There is no stability to this concept."Springboarding From MexicoLeading up to the 1968 Olympics, 18-year-old Spitz looked good in the pool. Yet in Mexico, Chavoor later reported, the teen's mental game was off — and Spitz fretted about a chronic sore throat.To win consistently on the world stage, Chavoor knew, Spitz had to banish bad thoughts. "Swimming is such an individual effort that once a competitor has doubts, he can't win," the coach stressed.Spitz did win, but not as much as he and many thought he should.After those Mexico City Games, Spitz headed to the University of Indiana. Hoosier swim coach Doc Counsilman rallied his team to support one another and build unity.That made a big difference for Spitz, who blossomed. "He became more interested in working out with the group. He was no longer a loner," Chavoor recalled.Spitz schooled himself in the dreaded butterfly, lurching through laps to the point of exhaustion. "It doesn't matter if you swim it slow or fast," he said. "It beats you up."Spitz knew he also needed a whale-sized goal to stay inspired.So he vowed to capture those record seven golds.Going into the Munich Games, he believed, he had to win his first event convincingly.He nailed it. "The relief of that first gold medal was so great that if I had quit then and there, I would have considered my years of hard work worth it," Spitz said.Back home after the Olympics, he was eating a bologna sandwich and planning his departure for dental school when the phone rang.It was Bob Hope."Back in the day, Bob Hope was as big as there was," said Evan Morgenstein, Spitz's agent.So Spitz got a sense of his star potential — and did something about it. Instead of dental school, he'd develop his brand, marry Suzy Weiner in 1973 and raise two sons.It's still panning out."He has a shelf life that goes beyond the Olympics," Morgenstein said. "He is still considered one of the greatest Olympians of all time."

As more consumers gravitate toward natural and organic fare, Target (TGT) is reportedly shifting focus from processed shelf staples — such as items from Campbell Soup (CPB), General Mills (GIS) and Kellogg (K) — in favor of promoting more health-focused products.
Target shares fell 0.4% to 78.19 in morning trading on the stock market today.

While canned soup and boxed cereal aren't being booted off shelves forever, they won't be in the spotlight, according to the Wall Street Journal. Items such as Greek yogurt and craft beer will get a bigger marketing push as Target aims to reach out to urban millennials.

Target, which sorts its merchandise into "signature", "outperform" and "perform" categories, doesn't promote its third-tier products as heavily. It is unclear where Campbell's chicken noodle soup or Kellogg's Pop-Tarts will get sorted.

The big box retailer is not the only one setting its sights on a younger demographic. Whole Foods Market (WFM) recently announced a plan to launch a new store concept that appeals to millennial shoppers with "modern" design, new technology and lower-cost products.

While the new Target arrangement isn't ideal for its longtime processed-food suppliers, this doesn't necessarily mean the end of premium shelf space for them. General Mills owns several organic and natural brands such as Larabar and recent acquisition Annie's, while Campbell owns Plum Organics in addition to its own line of organic soup.
Target reports earnings Wednesday. Analysts expect earnings of $1.02 per share on revenue of $17.08 billion.
Follow Elaine Low on Twitter: @IBD_ELow.

Stock futures changed their tune and pointed to a slightly weaker start for the stock market today. Nasdaq 100 futures fell 5 points vs. fair value, and S&P 500 futures lost a point. Futures on the Dow Jones industrial average gave up 12 points.
The stock market ended a six-week winning streak last week amid a pickup in distribution days, which prompted a downgrade of the market outlook.

Stock markets overseas were mixed. In Europe, France's CAC-40 slipped 0.2% after Friday's series of attacks by the Islamic State that left more than 100 dead. Germany's DAX rose 0.2%, and London's FTSE climbed 0.3%.
In Asia, Hong Kong's Hang Seng fell 1%, and Japan's Nikkei slumped 1.7%. But the Shanghai composite reversed higher to a 0.7% gain.
Crude oil jumped more than 2% to $41.68 a barrel on potential supply disruptions. Oil prices hit their lowest levels in over two months last week.
Safe-haven instruments such as bonds and the dollar were trading higher. Gold was also higher, up about 1% to $1,091.20 an ounce.
In economic news, the Empire State index for November came in at minus 10.7 vs. the consensus estimate of minus 5 from Econoday.
A number of central bank officials will be speaking throughout the week, starting Tuesday with Fed Governor Jerome Powell. The minutes from the Fed's October meeting are due Wednesday.

In stocks, Starwood Hotels & Resorts (HOT) fell 6% in premarket trading despite news of it being bought by Marriott International (MAR) for $12.2 billion in cash and stock. The deal would create the world's biggest hotel chain.

Dillard's (DDS) slumped 10% in premarket trading after posting disappointing quarterly results. The department store operator said it earned $1.19 a share, including an after-tax credit of 16 cents a share. Sales slipped to $1.435 billion. Views were for EPS of $1.20 on revenue of $1.49 billion. Rival Macy's (M) plunged 20% last week on disappointing quarterly sales and a weak outlook.

Airline stocks were lower in premaket activity on concerns on Friday's attacks on tourism. Shares of American Airlines Group (AAL), Delta Air Lines (DAL), United Continental (UAL) and Ryanair (RYAAY) were off more than 1%.
Both the NYSE and the Nasdaq will observe a minute of silence at 9:25 a.m. ET for the victims in the Paris terrorist attack Friday.

Packaged-foods company ConAgra Foods (CAG) lowered its fourth-quarter earnings estimate due to weak appetites for private-label brands and a slide in its consumer-foods segment.Guidance is now set at 55 cents per share vs. its earlier view of "slightly in excess" of 60 cents a share. Analysts expect 62 cents.The Omaha-based company attributed the outlook cut to a 7% quarterly volume decline in the consumer-foods segment and weak profits in the private-label unit.But lowering guidance has become common practice for ConAgra, said Morningstar analyst Erin Lash in a research note. The company previously lowered its near-term earnings outlook back in February, again reflecting weaknesses in its consumer-foods and private-label segments."I can't recall any other major packaged food firms repeatedly lowering guidance quarter-after-quarter of late," said Lash in an email to IBD.Shares of ConAgra sank 8% on the stock market today. Rivals Kraft (KRFT) and General Mills (GIS) both dipped 0.2%.ConAgra acquired Ralcorp Holdings at the end of 2012, making it the biggest private-brand packaged-food business in North America by sales. But it will take time to fully integrate the new takeover.Lash said she sees the Ralcorp acquisition favorably since it will strengthen ConAgra's relationship with retailers, "but incremental product innovation and marketing support investments for its brands and private-label will be needed to put it on more stable ground."ConAgra has a slew of household names in its pantry. Its consumer-foods segment includes brands such as Bertolli, Orville Redenbacher's, Hebrew National, Slim Jim and Hunt's. Chef Boyardee was singled out by the company as one of the retail brands that is primarily proving to have profit challenges.And Q4 operating profit for private-label brands is expected to decrease by about $60 million, said the company. The segment's issues were noted in March, when it blamed below-expected profitability on "sales force and supply chain transition issues, as well as pricing actions implemented in response to competitive pressure."The company will report Q4 earnings on June 26."We've long held a more conservative stance on ConAgra's prospects, given it operates with a portfolio of second- and third-tier brands and its profitability pales in comparison to peers (10% versus high-teens operating margins)," said Lash in the research note. "However, this revision is even more dire than we expected, and we plan to lower our near-term profit outlook."

B&G; Foods (BGS) boasts a hefty dividend yield even though its stock price has shot up over the past month following an acquisition. The annual dividend of $1.40 a share carries an annualized yield of about 4% at the current share price, nearly double the S&P; 500 average. The long-term dividend growth rate is also strong at 17%.B&G;, which makes hot sauce, canned food and seasoning, soared nearly 19% in the week ended Sept. 4 after announcing plans to buy frozen- and canned-vegetable producers Green Giant and Le Sueur from General Mills (GIS). The $765 million cash deal is expected to close by year-end.B&G; sees the acquisition helping it expand from the grocery aisles to the freezer section, "which we believe will open many future growth opportunities," B&G; CEO Robert Cantwell said Sept. 3.Analysts largely agreed."Green Giant is a transformative transaction that should accelerate the company's earnings, cash flow and likely the dividend," noted a Sept. 4 report from Stephens, which raised its rating on the stock to overweight from equal weight.B&G; has paid quarterly dividends since its initial public offering in 2004.It cut the payout by 20% during the 2008-09 recession and held it steady at 17 cents a share until increases resumed in 2011.The latest hike was announced in July, up a penny, or 3%, to 35 cents a share.B&G; is among the top stocks in the packaged-food industry, which was ranked 34th out of 197 as of Friday's IBD.The three-year earnings stability factor is 2 on a scale of zero to 99, with zero being most stable. The three-year earnings growth rate is 3%, and the sales growth rate is 15%.B&G; has been growing through acquisitions. Cantwell said the Green Giant and Le Sueur brands will generate annual net sales of $550 million.

Hillary Clinton's tweet about high drug prices knocked the stuffing out of drug and biotech stocks Monday, sending the Nasdaq into negative territory before it recovered to close with a modest gain.The Nasdaq, heavy in drug and biotech names, eked out a tiny gain, while the Dow Jones industrial average gained 0.8% and the S&P; 500 rose 0.5% in the stock market today. Volume was lower than Friday's monster trade on both the NYSE and Nasdaq exchanges.The biotech industry group fell 5.4%, the day's worst performer out of 197 groups. Generic drugs fell 3.1% and branded drugs dropped 3%.Clinton's tweet said she would soon release a plan to bring down the price of high-cost drugs.The best-performing industry groups were mainly defensive, such as food wholesalers, drug stores and tobacco companies.The housing industry group fell 0.7%. Lennar reported third-quarter EPS above estimates. After a morning pop, the stock closed 0.3% lower in above-average volume.Before the market opens Tuesday, Darden Restaurants (DRI) and General Mills (GIS) will report earnings. Analysts are expecting Darden to report EPS of 57 cents a share, a 78% improvement from a year ago. General Mills is forecast to report 69 cents a share, a 13% increase.

Omar Bradley knew who scaled history's heights on D-Day. "No soldier in my command," wrote the general after overseeing the Army at the Normandy invasion of June 6, 1944, "has ever been wished a more difficult task than that which befell the 34-year-old commander of the Provisional Ranger Force."That commander? Earl Rudder.When Bradley sought a man of steel to lead men up the cliff of Pointe du Hoc and nail the Nazis, he turned to the tenacious Texan.Lt. Col. Rudder came through. His triumph high above the Normandy coast helped D-Day deck the Germans from the west as the Russians rushed from the east — and in 11 months World War II in Europe was over."Pure leadership," Patrick O'Donnell, author of "Dog Company," told IBD. "He was a leader of men. He had mental toughness. He was determined. It was in his DNA. And to think the whole operation might not have succeeded if he had not been there."Douglas Brinkley, author of "The Boys of Pointe Du Hoc," put it this way: "James Rudder was the best of the U.S. military tradition. As an officer, he was one with his men. He was the perfect leader."This was a man who went on a suicide mission, and it's one of the most remarkable stories of World War II. He told his men they had a 50% chance of making it alive. And when his superiors told him not to go himself, he insisted. No way would he send them on that mission and not put his own life on the line."GroundedThomas Hatfield, author of "Rudder: From Leader to Legend," also raves: "He was simply an authentic person who had a calling in his life. He was very purposeful, with values that were as firm as was his character. He was one of the greatest citizen soldiers. The greatest, of course, was George Washington, who left the Army after the Revolution and returned to farming. Rudder was a reservist. He didn't make the Army a career. He wanted to return to civilian life for two reasons: an attachment to his mother and an attachment to Texas, to ranching. He was a man of the soil."When Rudder retired from the Army Reserve in 1967, while president of Texas A&M; University, he was a major general whose top decoration was the Distinguished Service Cross, a military award second only to the Medal of Honor.His men never forgot.Rudder was "one of the greatest men that ever lived," said Pvt. Jack Keating, one of the 2nd Ranger Battalion GIs who hit Pointe du Hoc.Heroic 1st Lt. Dutch Vermeer said that seeing Rudder "control the operation saved our day on Pointe du Hoc. In spite of his wounds, he was in command all the time."Star Ranger Leonard Lomell said: "He inspired you to do your best. You just wanted to die for him."Rudder almost died on that day 71 years ago. He was wounded twice at the Pointe, once by a bullet in his calf, and minutes later when an explosion fired cement fragments into his chest and arm.Meanwhile, as Rudder's Rangers ran into a Nazi gantlet above the coast of France, "he had to cope with the unknown," said Hatfield. "He and his men were cut off, isolated. They had no communication with commanders at sea. They didn't know the outcome of the invasion. Yet Rudder was steadfast without knowing when relief was coming. He remained calm, a dedicated leader. Some of his men told me they were better soldiers with him than at other times. That's because he was consistent, whatever the circumstances. He was always the same, authentic leader — and with him, his men knew the mission came first."James Earl Rudder (1910-70) developed his traits growing up poor in tiny Eden in central Texas."The family was stoic, and he became a man who was not easily ruffled," said Hatfield, who witnessed that character while with the Army Reserve in the 1960s. "He was also extraordinarily competitive."Rudder played football well enough in high school to get a ticket out of isolated Eden to play at John Tarleton Agricultural College, a few hours north in Stephenville. And play he did. Other than football, he had little use for the junior college (now four-year Tarleton State University) and quit.Yet he returned, completed two years and vaulted to Texas A&M;, where he landed a bachelor's degree in industrial education.The Depression kept him from pursuing his career for a year, but in the fall of 1933 he hooked up as a football coach and teacher of history and math in Brady, just east of Eden. "He was a very conscientious teacher. And he made no compromises with his football players," said Hatfield. "In fact, he was more demanding of them. The main thing was preparation. He lived in the future. He did not think about the past. That all carried over to Pointe du Hoc."Rudder had been commissioned an officer in the Army Reserve out of A&M;, and by 1937 he was married to Margaret Williamson and on the way to having five children.With America gearing up for WWII, he entered active duty in June 1941 and rose to major in July 1943 upon taking over the 2nd Ranger Battalion, then was promoted to lieutenant colonel that November. He put his men through the wringer of assault training at various U.S. bases.At the start, his men "were a disaster," said O'Donnell. "They couldn't do parade formation or much else. But Rudder the football coach turned them into a unit obsessed with winning. It all emanates from Rudder. He turned raw recruits into soldiers who could act on their own initiative and change the course of a battle."By early 1944, Rudder was in England and received details of the mission. In May, wrote Brinkley, he "laid out the plan for his men. . . . The Rangers' task: climb the cliffs and destroy the Nazi concrete bunkers 4 miles west of Omaha Beach on the Normandy coast. The Nazis had a battery of six 155 mm guns, with a range of 14 miles, on top of the Pointe between Utah and Omaha beaches aimed at the boats and men storming in. From their jutting crow's nest, the Germans could inflict great damage to the Allies' armada of over 5,000 ships."Added Brinkley: "To neutralize these enemy guns, this elite group of about 225 2nd Ranger Battalion volunteers — Rudder's Rangers — had to surprise the enemy by scaling the 100-foot-tall promontory, even while under a barrage of Nazi fire coming from a concrete observation post. It was a daunting assignment."To say the least. One naval officer said flatly, "It can't be done. Three old women with brooms could keep the Rangers from climbing those cliffs."Said O'Donnell: "It was definitely one of the most dangerous missions of World War II and American history. The Rangers had to fight through a 'Guns of Navarone'-like fortress atop the cliff filled with bunkers, tunnels and artillery, and machine gun nests."After crossing the English Channel, Rudder wasted little time, noted Brinkley: "Setting a fearless example for his men, (he) was on the first (assault craft) to land. . . . He raced to the cliff and established a small headquarters in a cave."The charge was made deadlier by the Nazis' MG 42, a savage machine gun called the Bonesaw. Rudder and his men still ascended with rope hung from hooks shot up the Pointe.Stratospheric ResultsAfter reaching the top — bombed by Allied planes that "turned it into something resembling the surface of the moon," said O'Donnell — the GIs followed tire tracks to the Nazi guns and used thermite grenades to disable them."The cliff climbing was tough enough," said O'Donnell. "The German counterattack the night of June 6 and the next day made it all the more difficult. First, the Americans ran out of ammo, so they had to use German guns. Then some of Rudder's men were taken prisoner."Rudder forged on with his next order: cutting the road between Utah and Omaha beaches."By June 8," wrote Brinkley, "the Americans were victorious at the Battle of Pointe du Hoc, raising the Stars and Stripes on the promontory. They had suffered 70% casualties. Yet their mission had been a military success."
