The maker of Horizon Organic Milk, Silk non-dairy milk and Earthbound Farms salads will report Q1 results Friday, and earnings are expected to come…

Army Col. James Van Fleet led his men on D-Day, but they landed at the wrong place on Utah Beach. "As commander of the 8th Infantry Regiment, 4th Division, he had learned to seize opportunities where he could, so he made the decision to move forward, leading from the front," Michael Haskew, author of "West Point 1915: Eisenhower, Bradley and the Class the Stars Fell On," told IBD. "He had overcome obstacles by sheer perseverance throughout his career that would have thwarted individuals of lesser constitution, taking the action he could wherever he was."Belatedly recognized for his leadership, he ended World War II as a major general.The next year, 1946, President Truman sent him to Greece to help the government defeat communist insurgents.Then in 1951, as a lieutenant general, he commanded Allied troops that routed North Korean and Chinese communists and was awarded the rank of full general."General Van Fleet is the greatest general we have ever had," said Truman. "I sent him to Greece and he won the war. I sent him to Korea and he won the war."Van Fleet (1892-1992) was born in Fort Lee, N.J., soon before his family moved to Bartow, Fla., when he was still an infant.To The PointHe entered the U.S. Military Academy at West Point in 1911, but was a slow reader who didn't have good study habits. He wrote to his father, saying he should probably drop out, but was encouraged to persevere. He told himself, "I can take it," a lesson he never forgot.He graduated in 1915 as a second lieutenant, among 36% of his class of 164 who were destined to become generals. Included were Dwight Eisenhower and Omar Bradley, who would receive five stars, and three would get four, one of them the late-bloomer Van Fleet.During leave on Christmas Day, Van Fleet married Helen Moore in Carnegie, Pa., and they would have two daughters and a son.After moving around the country as an instructor in the run-up to WWI, he joined the 16th Machine Gun Battalion of the 6th Division as it set sail for France in July 1918.First Lt. Van Fleet was soon in the trenches, and in November — the month the war ended — was wounded by a bomb.He returned home in June 1919.Van Fleet rose to major the next year and taught military leadership at Kansas State. Then he did the same at the University of Florida while coaching the football team to winning seasons in 1923 and 1924.By 1927 he was at Fort Benning, Ga., where Lt. Col. George Marshall was innovating infantry tactics.Van Fleet rose to lieutenant colonel in 1936 while training reserves in San Diego. Three years later the Nazis invaded Poland, so he was called back to Fort Benning to command 1st Battalion, 29th Infantry Regiment, which would demonstrate tactics to other units.In June 1941, Van Fleet assumed the rank of colonel and took over the 8th Infantry Regiment."Many of his classmates had been rapidly promoted, and it was alleged that the reason for his career stagnation was that Marshall, who was named Army chief of staff in 1939, had confused him with an alcoholic officer with a similar name," said Steve Taaffe, author of "Marshall and His Generals." "Instead of becoming bitter and despondent, though, Van Fleet focused on the task at hand, even if it was beneath his talents. Generals Eisenhower, Bradley and Joe Lawton Collins were said to have eventually cleared up the matter with Marshall."On June 6, 1944, at 4 a.m., the 8th Regiment was headed for the wrong landing point in the chaos of the invasion of Normandy, France, with Van Fleet initially behind in a command ship."After more than three years of training and planning, it was the first to make an amphibious landing on Utah Beach," wrote Paul Braim in "The Will to Win: The Life of General James A. Van Fleet." "The lessons learned would save lives, and then-Capt. George Mabry, remembering his moment of trial after retirement as a major general with a Medal of Honor, said Van Fleet was 'the best leader I have ever encountered, and I've encountered a lot of them.'"Van Fleet joined his men on the beach and led them deeper into Normandy. His jeep roamed the front line over the next four days, and he was slightly wounded.Bradley was astounded at what he saw and gave Van Fleet his first of three Distinguished Service Crosses, the military's second highest award, on the spot.The regiment continued to lead the division in fierce fighting over the next two weeks that ended with the capture of Cherbourg."He worked hard to gain intimate knowledge of his unit's personnel and operation, studying and analyzing not only the manpower, firepower and terrain under his control, but the same features for the enemy," said Keith Huxen, senior research director at the National WW2 Museum in New Orleans. "He knew that he would be successful if he mastered these details."A StarIn August, Van Fleet became a brigadier general, and in October took over the 90th Division, which had lagged at Normandy.He promptly made the outfit live up to its nickname, the Tough Ombres. Recalled one of its GIs, "He acted as if he expected success, and he got it."In November, the same month Van Fleet was made major general, the retrained 90th had its first big test in an assault across the Moselle River toward Germany.His men took heavy casualties the first three days, then pushed the enemy back. "Swiftness, mobility, unrelenting attack — these were Van Fleet's principles, in football as in war," wrote Braim. "He would regard the Moselle campaign as his finest hour."The 90th pursued the retreating Germans to the Siegfried Line near the Saar River, where the defensive barrier of the border of Germany was most highly developed.The Americans made a surprise attack in December and, despite strong resistance, pushed inland, capturing many prisoners.Just then, the 90th rushed north to counter the German offensive that was the Battle of the Bulge.In March 1945, Bradley urgently ordered Van Fleet to take over III Corps, which had just crossed the Rhine River at Remagen, Germany, the first major unit to do so.By mid-April, Van Fleet had directed III Corps' encirclement of the industrial heartland of the Ruhr Valley and captured over 100,000 prisoners. The Nazi high command surrendered on May 7.All Over The MapVan Fleet arrived home in June and took over the 2nd Service Command in New York City. The unit involved the Army Reserve.In February 1948, Truman promoted him to lieutenant general and put him in charge of helping the Greek government defeat the insurgency backed by the Soviet Union. Starting with a poorly armed and badly led force, Van Fleet oversaw $300 million in aid, equipment and training, and by 1950 his Greeks had triumphed.Van Fleet returned to Washington and helped the Army prepare a response to the North Korean invasion of the South in June 1950.In September, Gen. Douglas MacArthur's U.S. and U.N. troops pushed back the communists and captured the North's capital.But in November, the Chinese army poured over the border, and the Allies were forced back into South Korea. Then came a political thunderstorm, with MacArthur criticizing the American strategy in public in March 1951 and Truman replacing him with Gen. Matthew Ridgway, commander of the 8th Army, the main U.S. force.Van Fleet was rushed to take over the 8th in April, and a week later a communist force of 700,000 struck. He directed a tactical withdrawal and blunted the offensive, inflicting 70,000 casualties.The 8th then pushed the communists north of the border, inflicting an additional 200,000 casualties.In July 1951, Van Fleet received his fourth star. Peace talks started the same month, but fighting continued.The next April, his son, a B-26 bomber pilot, was shot down over North Korea and died.The general left for home in early 1953 and retired. The armistice was signed that July.Van Fleet lived to 100 and died at his ranch near Polk City, Fla.

Leslie Sabo was killed during the Vietnam War's 1970 Cambodian Campaign. He was nominated for the Medal of Honor, but the records were lost until a veteran rediscovered them in 1999. In 2012, Sabo's widow received the nation's highest military award on his behalf, the 249th for Vietnam.Sabo's platoon and another had been ambushed from all sides by a large and well-entrenched force of communist soldiers.He repeatedly attacked and killed enemy soldiers, was wounded by a grenade as he shielded a comrade, and then was fatally shot as he provided covering fire for a medevac helicopter.Honored"His indomitable courage and complete disregard for his own safety saved the lives of many of his platoon members," said the Medal of Honor citation. "Spc. 4 Sabo's extraordinary heroism and selflessness, above and beyond the call of duty, at the cost of his life, are in keeping with the highest traditions of military service and reflect great credit upon himself, Company B, 3rd Battalion, 506th Infantry, 101st Airborne Division, and the United States Army."Leslie Jr. was born in 1948 in Kufstein, Austria, where his well-to-do family had moved after the Soviet occupation of Hungary at the end of World War II, leaving almost everything behind.They moved to America when he was 2. They lived in Youngstown, Ohio, and then Ellwood City, Pa.Leslie Sr., a lawyer in Hungary, retrained as an engineer, and both parents taught their two remaining sons (another was killed by a bomb during the war) patriotism for their adopted country."Les was an average student, but had a lot of friends and always showed he really cared about people," his older brother, George, told IBD. "He attended Youngstown State for a couple of semesters, but his grades weren't great, so he took a break. Four months later, in April 1969, he was drafted into the Army, and while we were concerned about his safety, we were very proud that he felt he was doing his duty. Because our family had barely escaped when the Russians came into Hungary, we thought it was important that communism be kept from spreading. A lot of his buddies didn't see it that way, and there were some intense arguments about the war."After basic training at Fort McClellan, Ala., Sabo qualified for advanced training and took leave to get married in September to Rose Mary Buccelli, whom he had met the year before."It was love at first sight," she said in "Forgotten Honor: The True Story of an American Hero" by Eric Poole, published in 2009 before the approval of the Sabo's Medal of Honor.In October, after training, the Sabos had a honeymoon. The next month, he was in South Vietnam as the war raged.Drenched And HitFrom December to April, his Bravo Company was in action all but two days, much of it in the tropical rain. Sabo displayed unusual courage in protecting his fellow GIs and was wounded, earning himself a Purple Heart and Bronze Star, the military's fourth highest honor for combat bravery."He was different from what many might think of as a war hero — low-key, polite, not loud and crazy like many guys," recalled Richard Rios, a machine-gunner who served with Sabo. "He never complained and was a good soldier. But the hero came out in battle when he protected his brothers."George talked with others in his platoon: "They said he wasn't one of those rah-rah guys, but he'd volunteer for the most hazardous missions and led on point for two months, so it's a miracle he survived as long as he did. When he was getting ready for battle, he went through a ritual of tying a bandana on his head and focusing, and everyone could see the transformation into a true warrior and knew he had their backs."For years, the North Vietnamese army had staged attacks on South Vietnam from Cambodia, knowing that it was U.S. policy to respect that country's official neutrality.Finally, President Nixon ordered a counteroffensive. U.S. and South Vietnam forces hit the North Vietnam Army (NVA) in Cambodia during the spring of 1970.The northern thrust was in the Se San Valley to disrupt the use of the Ho Chi Minh Trail to bring down supplies from North Vietnam.In The Thick Of ItOperation Binh Tay — meaning "tame the west" — borrowed Sabo's 506th Regiment (from the 101st Airborne Division), based near the border between North and South Vietnam, and put it under control of the 4th Infantry Division to spearhead its wing of the mission.The 506th was nicknamed the Currahees, Cherokee for "we stand alone," and was one of the Army's most storied units, having been among the first parachuting infantry, landing behind the lines during the D-Day invasion in June 1944."The 'Currahees' of Bravo Company, 3-506th, had been involved in skirmishes with NVA soldiers practically from the time they set foot on Cambodian soil," wrote Jerald Berry in "Twelve Days in May." "The first line of defense for the line company was the firepower of the individual weapons of the infantrymen — M-16 rifles, M-60 machine guns and M-79 grenadiers (grenade launchers). If more firepower was required to subdue the enemy, the commanding officer could call for artillery support from the battalion fire support base."After destroying North Vietnamese army field hospitals and hamlets where the enemy was based, Sabo's 2nd Platoon, along with the 3rd, headed for another hamlet on May 10. At 3:15 p.m., they came to a clearing amid thick brush and trees. The Americans advanced into it warily until a big NVA force opened up, some members shooting down from the treetops.The Mother's Day Ambush was on. With some protection from bushes and small trees, the GIs fired back. Sabo neared enemy trenches to kill several NVA soldiers and prevent a flanking move.While he gave first aid to a wounded comrade, grenades landed at their position. Sabo covered the GI and took fragment wounds in his back. Even so, he killed two of the communist attackers and moved the wounded man to safety.With his platoon low on ammo, Sabo retrieved belts from the dead and redistributed them, but he was hit by small arms fire. Now bleeding profusely, he fired back, giving others time to crawl to safety.By nightfall, 1st Platoon, which had been held in reserve, came to their relief, while helicopters tried to medevac the wounded. Sabo shook off his wounds and stepped into the open to shoot any NVA soldier who fired at the chopper. Giving up himself for his comrades, he moved toward the enemy. He took more bullets and then, as he was reloading, was shot dead. He was 22."We had to call in artillery on top of us to keep from being overrun," said Rios. "The 105 mm howitzer rounds were detonating at treetop level, and shrapnel flew all over us as well as the enemy. I had been in firefights before, but not this big, as long or intense."Seven other members of 2nd Platoon were killed and 28 wounded — the most casualties of the three platoons; virtually everyone had been hit — before the communists slumped away with heavy losses. The ambush was the worst battle during the 12 days that the 506th was in Cambodia.The Cambodian Campaign ended by July. The Paris peace treaty was signed in 1973. The North Vietnamese shredded that agreement by overrunning the South in 1975 — and the recommendation for Sabo's Medal of Honor got lost.Then in 1999, Alton Mabb, a columnist for the 101st Airborne Division Association's Screaming Eagle magazine, came across the paperwork at the National Archives.None of Sabo's family or friends knew how he had been killed. The Medal of Honor recognizes those whose valor saved lives. The standards to qualify are extraordinarily high, with two-thirds of recipients since 1941 having been awarded it posthumously.Unlike any other award, it has to be approved by the entire command, including the secretary of the military branch, the secretary of defense and the president.During the long lobbying to recognize Sabo's heroism, he was promoted posthumously to sergeant.Then came a call that Rose will never forget. "On Feb. 1, 2012, the telephone on Rose Sabo-Brown's computer desk jangled to life," wrote Poole in the newly published "Company of Heroes: A Forgotten Medal of Honor and Bravo Company's War in Vietnam." "A few minutes later, President Barack Obama came on the line and told her that the husband whose death had left her a widow more than four decades earlier would receive the U.S. military's highest honor for combat valor. With the president's call, the United States completed one of its last remaining items of business from the Vietnam War."
Herbal tea, cold-pressed juice, Greek-style yogurt, organic chips, almond milk.
If you've purchased these kinds of health-oriented products, there's a good chance at least some of them come from one company: Hain Celestial Group (HAIN).
Hain sells hundreds of natural and organic products under brands such as Celestial Seasonings, Terra, Garden of Eatin', Health Valley, WestSoy and Earth's Best.
And that's just a starter list.
"They probably have the best and broadest exposure to the natural foods industry in all channels of distribution," said analyst Scott Van Winkle of Canaccord Genuity.
It's a good place to be these days. Organic and natural foods are growing at a blended rate of at least 11% a year, Van Winkle says. Conventional food is growing in the low single digits at best.

Hain has logged double-digit sales and profit gains every quarter for more than three years. During its fiscal third quarter, which ended March 31, revenue grew 22% from the prior year to a record $557.4 million. Earnings also rose 22%, to 88 cents per share.
A Natural Choice
"(Hain) is a very good play on the core growth of natural and organic foods," Van Winkle said.
Major customers include Wal-Mart (WMT) as well as United Natural Foods (UNFI), a distributor that sells to Whole Foods Market (WFM) and other outlets.
Hain also sells to traditional grocery chains such as Kroger (KR), Safeway (SWY), Wegmans and Publix.
Thanks to health and dietary concerns, the kind of natural and organic foods and personal-care products Hain sells have been gaining shelf space in traditional grocery channels.
"That is where the growth is coming from," Irwin Simon, Hain's chief executive, said in an interview. "We've seen the shift in the last couple of years."
He says about 60% of Hain's U.S. sales come from traditional grocery stores.
Rivals run the gamut from large packaged foods companies such as Kraft (KRFT) and General Mills (GIS) to small organic-food players such as Annie's (BNNY).
"Given that Hain has such broad exposure, it has hundreds of competitors," Van Winkle said.
Meanwhile, the company's sales outside the U.S. have been increasing. They represented 42.7% of the total during the fiscal third quarter, up from 17.9% in 2011.

The U.K. is still Hain's biggest overseas market, with 32% of Q3 revenue. Hain's product mix in Britain includes a larger mix of mainstream grocery items than in the U.S., such as jams, peanut butter and desserts.
To feed consumers' hankering for organic and natural foods in the U.S. and elsewhere, Hain keeps rolling out new products and adding new brands through acquisitions.

Last year it launched 125 new products, Simon says, though it discontinued some others. New products rolled out this year ranged from snacks, soups and shakes to gluten-free pasta and personal-care items.
It's also been a big year for acquisitions, continuing a strategy Simon began in 1993 after he acquired struggling Hain Pure Food from Pet Inc.
Simon says his strategy has always been to "buy brands started by someone else," and then "figure out how to grow them from there."
In January, Hain spent $357 million to buy Tilda Ltd., a premium Basmati and specialty-rice company based in the UK, with sales in more than 40 countries.

Also this year, Hain acquired Rudi's Organic Bakery, which makes a popular organic bread. And last week Hain bought the remaining 51.3% interest it didn't already own in antibiotic-free and organic poultry brands FreeBird chicken and Plainville Farms turkey.
Organic baby foods company Ella's Kitchen Group was added last year, expanding Hain's large reach into the baby market, where Earth's Best sells everything from infant formula to diapers.
In December 2012, Hain bought cold-pressed juice business BluePrint Cleanse, putting Hain in a market that is "very on trend," Van Winkle said.

Even old trends still have juice. For example, the Celestial Seasonings tea brand contributes only 6% to 7% of overall sales but produces margins that are "quite good," Piper Jaffray analyst Sean Naughton noted in a report earlier this month.
In addition, he says, tea comes with "steady profitability" and cash flow that can be invested in other areas of the business.
As calming as tea is for Hain, Wal-Mart's expanded rollout of organic products through the Wild Oats brand may cause some stress among organic-food players.
"With Wal-Mart launching Wild Oats at lower prices, our concern is that it could put downward price pressure on the organic category," said John Baumgartner, analyst with Wells Fargo Securities.
Immaterial Threat?
Since Hain has such a diversified product mix in organic products, it might feel the price pinch more than other companies with a narrower focus, he says.

Even so, Naughton views the Wild Oats threat as "largely immaterial" to Hain, based not on pricing pressures but on the fact that Hain and Wild Oats directly compete on only a small percentage of products.
Assuming 20% to 30% cannibalization in affected categories, he figured "a modest" headwind to Hain's revenue growth over the next 12 months.

Another potential risk comes from United Natural Foods, which looks to improve inventory turns by buying fewer units from suppliers. Hain is "navigating the headwind by better product sales in other channels," Naughton said. However, United Natural's inventory-reduction program took away "some upside" to his revenue estimates for Hain.

Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters estimate Hain will post earnings of $3.16 a share for all of fiscal 2014, up 25% from last year. Revenue is expected to rise 24% to $2.15 billion.Herbal tea, cold-pressed juice, Greek-style yogurt, organic chips, almond milk.If you've purchased these kinds of health-oriented products, there's a good chance at least some of them come from one company: Hain Celestial Group (HAIN).Hain sells hundreds of natural and organic products under brands such as Celestial Seasonings, Terra, Garden of Eatin', Health Valley, WestSoy and Earth's Best.And that's just a starter list."They probably have the best and broadest exposure to the natural foods industry in all channels of distribution," said analyst Scott Van Winkle of Canaccord Genuity.It's a good place to be these days. What's even better than a company that pays big dividends? One that raises its payout on a fairly regular basis. The dividend growth rate shows investors how fast a stock's dividend is growing over a set period. IBD calculates the annualized growth rate over three to five years. The rate is published in each day's Dividend Leaders, Utility Leaders and REIT Leaders tables.
Today we'll look at the six Dividend Leaders with the highest growth rates.

Cisco Systems (CSCO) comes out on top with a dividend growth rate of 38%. The networking gear maker in February raised its payout by 2 cents to 21 cents a share, or 84 cents for the full year. That works out to an annualized yield near 3%, ahead of the S&P 500's 1.94%.
Cisco has more than tripled its dividend since it began offering a quarterly payout of 6 cents a share in 2011. The stock is working on a cup base with a potential buy point at 30.41.

Lorillard (LO) is second with a 30% growth rate. The tobacco maker, which is seeking FTC approval for its merger with Reynolds American (RAI), recently boosted its dividend by 7% to 66 cents, for a 3.7% yield. Shares are just above a 69.71 flat-base buy point.

Western Union's (WU) 22% rate is just ahead of Lockheed Martin's (LMU) 21%. The payment service firm pays 55.1 cents a share for an annualized yield of 3%. The F-35 maker's $1.50-a-share dividend works out to 3% also. Lockheed was featured in Tuesday's column.

General Electric's (GE) quarterly payout of 24 cents a share yields 3.4% based on its current stock price. The industrial conglomerate has a dividend growth rate of 18%. On April 17, it posted Q1 profit that topped views, but sales missed. The stock is back below a 27.20 entry.

General Mills (GIS) rounds out the top six with an 11% growth rate. The Cheerios maker last month raised its quarterly dividend by 7% to 44 cents a share, or $1.76 for the full year, for a 3.1% yield. Shares are just above a 55.74 buy point of a flat base cleared March 30.What's even better than a company that pays big dividends? One that raises its payout on a fairly regular basis. The industrial conglomerate has a dividend growth rate of 18%. On April 17, it posted Q1 profit that topped views, but sales missed. The stock is back below a 27.20 entry.General Mills (GIS) rounds out the top six with an 11% growth rate. The Cheerios maker last month raised its quarterly dividend by 7% to 44 cents a share, or $1.76 for the full year, for a 3.1% yield. Shares are just above a 55.74 buy point of a flat base cleared March 30.

Today's IBD 50 features a pair of deliciously rated food companies, energy drink maker Monster Beverage (MNST) and organic and natural food and beverage maker WhiteWave. The announcement last…
General Mills (GIS) issued fiscal third-quarter earnings and sales that topped expectations Wednesday, but currency translation weighed on the packaged foods manufacturer's results.

The maker of Cheerios, Betty Crocker and Progresso products earned 70 cents in Q3, a 12.9% increase from last year. Currency fluctuations reduced General Mills' adjusted EPS by approximately 1 cent, the company said. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters were expecting 67 cents.
Revenue fell 0.6% to $4.351 billion, edging estimates for $4.346 billion, with a four percentage-point impact from foreign currency exchange.
Shares dipped 1.1% to 51.49 on the stock market today. The stock has been consolidating between 48 and 56 since last June.

General Mills reaffirmed its full-year guidance. It expects 2015 EPS to grow at a low single-digit rate in constant currency from last year's $2.82. At current exchange rates, General Mills estimates that currency translation will reduce EPS by 7 cents. Analysts have calculated $2.82.
The company sees revenue also growing at a low single-digit rate, on a constant currency basis, from 2014's $17.9 billion. Wall Street has projected revenue to edge down 0.2% to $17.87 billion.
General Mills' international segment sales dropped 7% to $1.23 billion in the quarter due to foreign exchange effects, which impacted growth by 13 percentage points, General Mills said.

The U.S. retail segment saw sales increase 1% to $2.65 billion, driven by the yogurt and snacks operating units. General Mills acquired Annie's, a maker of organic snack products, in October 2014, which also contributed to the top line. But the segment's meals and baking products units posted declines for the quarter.
For the convenience stores and food-service segment, sales grew 6% to $465 million, lead by frozen breakfast items, yogurt and cereal.

General Mills has a low IBD Composite Rating of 49 out of 99. That means its shares outperform only 49% of all stocks in the market as measured by fundamental and technical factors. Some of those factors are earnings and sales growth, return on equity, profit margins and relative price performance.

The Food-Packaged group is ranked No. 121 out of the 197 industry groups that IBD tracks. Hain Celestial (HAIN), which packages natural and organic foods and other products, leads the group with a 95 Composite Rating, followed by WhiteWave Foods (WWAV), which has a 92 Composite Rating.
Hain shares fell 1.9% to 62.24 Wednesday, while WhiteWave fell 1% to 41.15.

Food shares are rallying as news of the Kraft Foods (KRFT) merger with ketchup giant H.J. Heinz is making investors' mouths water.Kraft is surging 41% near noon in the stock market today on the news that Heinz owners 3G Capital and Berkshire Hathaway will buy the cheese and snack maker.Shares of Oreo maker Mondelez International (MDLZ) — a Kraft spinoff — are up 2.6%. Cereal giant General Mills (GIS) shares ticked up 2.4%. Dean Foods (DF) rose 1.9%. J.M. Smucker (SJM) shares 2.3%. ConAgra Foods (CAG) shares edged up 1.4%. Kellogg (K) also climbed 1.4%.Natural food makers Hain Celestial (HAIN) shares rose 2.9% and WhiteWave Foods (WWAV) shares bumped up 1.7%, both hitting new highs.Campbell Soup (CPB) shares essentially remained flat, edging up 0.3%.Berkshire Hathaway (BRKA) A-class and Berkshire (BRKB) B-class shares edged lower.Looking further down the road, Mondelez, Pinnacle Foods (PF) and B&G Foods (BG) could potentially benefit from the merger, according to RBC Capital Markets analyst David Palmer.If Kraft moves to sell non-core businesses like frozen foods, Birds Eye parent Pinnacle could be a potential buyer, while B&G might eye Kraft's other non-core brands, said Palmer in a note.And Palmer speculates that Mondelez could be the next big acquisition target.According to a recent PwC report, merger deals may be key in streamlining increasingly large portfolios."M&A is likely to become increasingly important, not just in growing food companies, but in streamlining and focusing them," it said.Other recent food mergers include Tyson Foods' (TSN) acquisition of Hillshire Brands and General Mills' buyout of Annie's.Follow Elaine Low on Twitter: @IBD_ELow.RELATED:3G Capital, Berkshire To Buy Kraft, Merge With Heinz.

Equity-income mutual funds were holding their own against the broad stock market in the past 10 years — until mid-2013. Then growth stocks starting asserting their strength in the broad market. That put dividend-focused equity-income mutual funds at a disadvantage.

You can see it in the chart showing what an investment of $10,000 made on June 30, 2005, would have grown to by Aug. 10 this year. That amount invested in the average equity-income mutual fund would have grown to $19,509, according to Morningstar. The same amount plunked into the S&P 500 would have increased to $21,845.

Invesco Diversified Dividend Fund rose an average annual 8.28% the past 10 years vs. 7.77% for the S&P 500. The $11.5 billion fund has generated a gain of 6% for investors this year vs. 4% for the S&P 500.

The fund has been managed by Meggan Walsh since 2002, and Robert Botard and Kristina Bradshaw since 2014. It has a 12 month yield of 1.35%, compared with 2.01% for the S&P 500, a proxy for the broad stock market.

Diversified Dividend's recent holdings include General Mills (GIS) and Campbell Soup (CBP). Cereal maker General Mills yields 3% and has a dividend growth rate of 11%, while Campbell yields 2.5% and has a dividend growth rate of 6%.

The fund's investment strategy pursues growth of capital and secondarily current income and principal preservation. At the end of Q2, the fund managers were focused on defensive businesses with sustainable operating profit margins and prudent capital allocation.

"We are finding that today's most promising opportunities are in companies that generate stable levels of high free cash flow, such as some of the fund's consumer staples holdings," the managers said in the June 30 commentary. The fund then was overweight in consumer staples, consumer discretionary and utilities. It was underweight in financials, energy, tech and health care.

Leading dividend stocks General Mills (GIS) and Kellogg (K) have risen sharply in recent weeks following better-than-expected earnings reports.

The results were helped by cost-cutting efforts as both companies try to compensate for declining U.S. cereal sales. Meanwhile, both are adapting to changing consumer preferences for healthier food by introducing gluten-free and organic products and doing away with artificial colors and flavors.

General Mills, whose brands include Cheerios, Wheaties and Betty Crocker, reported July 1 that profit for its fiscal fourth quarter rose 12% from the same period last year to 75 cents a share, beating Wall Street estimates. Sales were flat at $4.3 billion.

The Minneapolis-based company recently said it would streamline its manufacturing and distribution network by closing two plants and cutting 620 jobs, adding to an earlier plan to eliminate up to 725 jobs.

Despite its struggles, General Mills' long-term dividend growth rate is a hefty 11%. The latest increase in the quarterly payout was announced March 10 — a 7% rise to 44 cents a share, or $1.76 annually. The annualized yield is 3%, well above the S&P 500 average.
The stock is up 11% this year and is in buy range after clearing a 57.83 buy point of a long flat base cleared in heavy volume on July 3.

Meanwhile, Kellogg is up 5% this year after rebounding following Q2 results announced Aug. 4. Profit fell 10% to 92 cents a share, in line with expectations. Sales fell 5% to $3.5 billion due to currency headwinds.
The stock has risen for five straight sessions as it nears a 69.98 buy point.
The maker of Frosted Flakes, Rice Krispies and other grain-based products has a long-term dividend growth rate of 5%.
Its annualized dividend yield is 2.9%.

The latest increase was announced July 24, a 2% gain to 50 cents a share payable Sept. 15 to shareholders of record on Sept. 1.Leading dividend stocks General Mills (GIS) and Kellogg (K) have risen sharply in recent weeks following better-than-expected earnings reports.The results were helped by cost-cutting efforts as both companies try to compensate for declining U.S. cereal sales. Taking on a business giant? Adopt this no-fear entrepreneurial mentality:

• Serve emerging tastes. For five years, Graze has been tempting consumers away from grocery-store snack aisles by delivering healthy treats to their mailboxes. The U.K.-headquartered firm tripled its U.S. subscribers to 150,000 since giving Americans a taste, starting in December.
CEO Anthony Fletcher says his company's technology is freshening up a stale sales model.
Graze's algorithm customizes each box based on a client's dietary needs, order history and feedback.
"We can base decisions on consumer behavior rather than market research," Fletcher told IBD.
• Master tools. Using similar technology, one of Graze's founders had pioneered Web-based distribution of DVD rentals and video streaming via Lovefilm, Great Britain's version of Netflix (NFLX).
Fletcher said snacking is simply another frontier: "It's a bit like fashion 10 years ago. People said selling clothes online would never work."
• Bring some personality. Who you are matters to customers. "You wrap an experience around the product," Fletcher said.
Proof that people — and competitors — are taking notice: General Mills (GIS) launched a similar service called Nibblr last November. "It's a validation, in a way," he said.

• Apply agility. Corporate giants' vulnerable spot? "They are usually bureaucratic and can't make decisions quickly. It's also a much bigger deal if a big company makes a mistake, and therefore they are more risk-averse," said Axosoft CEO Hamid Shojaee.
This year, his firm began offering a $1-per-year bug-tracking tool, used by software developers to find defects, to tempt customers away from competitors.

• Take leaps."Dumb, blind determination." That's what turned former pharmaceutical sales executive Bryan Batten into an e-book bootstrapper. His inspiration came from weeklong business trips. He grew weary lugging around the two or three books he read while killing time in airports. "I thought: There has to be a better way."

• Lead with confidence. Armed with the germ of an idea for a monthly e-book subscription service, Entitle, Batten approached industry insiders. "I heard 'no' so many times," he said. What kept him pressing forward? "I knew we were creating something good."
• Find sweet spots. Batten knew he had to be different to grab customers from competitors, including emerging subscription e-book services and Amazon (AMZN).

A key difference: Entitle customers own the books even if they quit the service, and subscribers can transfer those tomes to various devices rather than being limited to one. "We have to be fanatical about how we treat our customers," he said. "We also have to be fanatical about how we treat the publishers."

• Tap the real world. "Wouldn't it be great if I had a solution to this problem?" That's what Myles Binford thought after his kids pressed him for their allowance. He didn't carry cash, and the kids didn't have checking accounts.
The solution he devised — Pocket Change — would allow the transferring of funds to kids' debit cards via a smartphone app.
Binford calls being a little guy, launching from day-to-day experience, an advantage.
"I'm actually developing this to mirror life," he said.

• Look beyond. Pocket Change started as a way to manage chores and pay kids for completing them, but Binford envisions wider potential as a person-to-person cash replacement: "If it really does solve problems, you'll find other applications. This is where disruption comes about."Taking on a business giant? Adopt this no-fear entrepreneurial mentality:• Serve emerging tastes. For five years, Graze has been tempting consumers away from grocery-store snack aisles by delivering healthy treats to their mailboxes. Using similar technology, one of Graze's founders had pioneered Web-based distribution of DVD rentals and video streaming via Lovefilm, Great Britain's version of Netflix (NFLX).Fletcher said snacking is simply another frontier: "It's a bit like fashion 10 years ago. Stocks opened to quiet, mild losses Wednesday.
The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 0.4%. The Nasdaq and the S&P 500 each dipped 0.2%.

Volume started softly on the stock market today, with trade on both the Nasdaq and NYSE exchanges tracking about 8% below levels at the same time on Tuesday. The Federal Open Market Committee's rate policy announcement, scheduled for 2 p.m. ET, promises to be an inflection point in the day's trading.

Big names in motion after quarterly reports included FedEx (FDX) (down 1.5%) and General Mills (GIS) (down 0.3%). Stocks moving on analyst upgrades and downgrades included Calumet Specialty Products Partners (CLMT), up 2% on an upgrade to outperform from RBC Capital markets, and MercadoLibre (MELI), down 2% on a downgrade to neutral from JPMorgan.

Adobe Systems (ADBE) crumpled 5% after reporting late Tuesday its fiscal first quarter earnings and revenue cleared consensus forecasts. Creative Cloud subscriptions rose about 28% during the quarter, just below expectations. Management also guided second quarter earnings below consensus expectations. The huge-volume, gap-down loss dragged the stock back from five days of gains, leaving it 5% below a Feb. 27 high and even with its 50-day moving average.

Akorn (AKRX) spiked 9%, easily scrambling to the top of the IBD 50 list. The company announced Tuesday it was restating some results from its Q2 and Q3 financial statements related to its acquisition of Hi-Tech Pharmacal in April. The gap up gain hoisted shares back above their 10-week moving average, lifting the stock's rebound to 16% so far this week.

At the bottom of the list, China-based Noah Holdings (NOAH) fell 5%, giving back most of the 6% gain in heavy trade posted on Tuesday. The stock is on the thinly traded side. Daily dollar volume is under $11 million.

Europe's top indexes were very mixed in afternoon trade, with London's FTSE 100 up 1% and Frankfurt's DAX down 0.5%. Exchanges in Paris, Frankfurt and London will all be closed before the Fed's announcement this afternoon.

The ink hasn't dried on the Kraft Foods (KRFT) merger with H.J. Heinz, but analysts already are speculating which brands may be sold and which food companies are next on the M&A menu.

3G Capital and Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway  (BRKA), which acquired Heinz in 2013, said Wednesday they will buy Kraft to forge Kraft Heinz Co. Kraft holders will get shares in the merged company, plus a special $16.50 a share dividend, paid for by $10 billion from 3G and Berkshire.
Kraft stock rose 35.6% to 83.17.

Kraft Heinz would be the world's No. 5 food and beverage company, with eight brands topping $1 billion in annual sales. It would team Kraft's Velveeta, Lunchables and Oscar Mayer with Heinz's flagship ketchup and baked beans.

The combined company may look to sell a few noncore or regional businesses, said RBC Capital Markets David Palmer in a note released before Wednesday's official confirmation. B&G Foods (BG) might be a buyer. And Heinz's frozen portfolio, which includes Weight Watchers Smart Ones and Ore Ida, might appeal to Pinnacle Foods (PF).
Last year, Hillshire Brands axed its quest for Pinnacle after agreeing to be acquired itself by meat producer Tyson Foods (TSN).
3G's past gives some hints about which businesses might be cut.

"A fair amount of brand pruning could be in the cards, similar to the actions 3G has taken since owning Heinz (such as shedding Shanghai Long Fong Foods in China and the U.S. foodservice dessert business in 2013)," said Morningstar analyst Erin Lash in a note.
Jell-O's standing, in particular, might look wobbly.

"We've thought for some time that Jell-O, which continues to falter despite multiple stabs at putting it on more stable ground, could be axed in favor of allocating more capital to faster-growing categories such as organics," Lash wrote, adding, "this could occur in a more rapid fashion under its new ownership."

As consumer tastes have veered toward more healthful fare, so too have packaged food giants. General Mills (GIS) bought natural-foods maker Annie's last year. Before that, Campbell Soup (CPB) bought baby food maker Plum Organics and salad dressing brand Bolthouse Farms.
WhiteWave Foods (WWAV), maker of Silk soy and almond milk, rose 1.3%. Hain Celestial (HAIN) hit 66.35 early, but closed up 0.6% at 63.83.
Among larger food stocks, Mondelez International (MDLZ) — which split from Kraft in 2012 — rose 2.3%. General Mills edged up 1% and Kellogg (K) 0.3%.

"While the possible purchase of Kraft makes another deal likely impossible for several years, ultimately we believe Mondelez to be the clear 'next deal,'" noted Palmer. It would "reunite Kraft's global grocery brands (e.g. Philadelphia) and give Heinz's international business needed scale."
But combining brands might not always be the best strategy, as a recent PwC report cautions.

"It's no longer an asset-based game. Large, diversified food companies are struggling to compete with smaller, more focused enterprises," noted authors J. Neely and John Potter. "These companies need to be thinking beyond scale about what it is they do better than anyone else."The ink hasn't dried on the Kraft Foods (KRFT) merger with H.J. It would team Kraft's Velveeta, Lunchables and Oscar Mayer with Heinz's flagship ketchup and baked beans.The combined company may look to sell a few noncore or regional businesses, said RBC Capital Markets David Palmer in a note released before Wednesday's official confirmation. B&G Foods (BG) might be a buyer. And Heinz's frozen portfolio, which includes Weight Watchers Smart Ones and Ore Ida, might appeal to Pinnacle Foods (PF).Last year, Hillshire Brands axed its quest for Pinnacle after agreeing to be acquired itself by meat producer Tyson Foods (TSN).3G's past gives some hints about which businesses might be cut."A fair amount of brand pruning could be in the cards, similar to the actions 3G has taken since owning Heinz (such as shedding Shanghai Long Fong Foods in China and the U.S. foodservice dessert business in 2013)," said Morningstar analyst Erin Lash in a note.Jell-O's standing, in particular, might look wobbly."We've thought for some time that Jell-O, which continues to falter despite multiple stabs at putting it on more stable ground, could be axed in favor of allocating more capital to faster-growing categories such as organics," Lash wrote, adding, "this could occur in a more rapid fashion under its new ownership."As consumer tastes have veered toward more healthful fare, so too have packaged food giants. General Mills (GIS) bought natural-foods maker Annie's last year. Before that, Campbell Soup (CPB) bought baby food maker Plum Organics and salad dressing brand Bolthouse Farms.WhiteWave Foods (WWAV), maker of Silk soy and almond milk, rose 1.3%. Hain Celestial (HAIN) hit 66.35 early, but closed up 0.6% at 63.83.Among larger food stocks, Mondelez International (MDLZ) — which split from Kraft in 2012 — rose 2.3%. General Mills edged up 1% and Kellogg (K) 0.3%."While the possible purchase of Kraft makes another deal likely impossible for several years, ultimately we believe Mondelez to be the clear 'next deal,'" noted Palmer. It would "reunite Kraft's global grocery brands (e.g. Philadelphia) and give Heinz's international business needed scale."But combining brands might not always be the best strategy, as a recent PwC report cautions."It's no longer an asset-based game. Large, diversified food companies are struggling to compete with smaller, more focused enterprises," noted authors J. Neely and John Potter. "These companies need to be thinking beyond scale about what it is they do better than anyone else."
General Mills (GIS) tumbled Monday after a Bank of America analyst downgraded the stock, concluding its valuation isn't warranted, given its earnings outlook.
It was the third straight session the stock has fallen, but it appeared to be finding support at its 10-week moving average.

"We are lowering our rating on (General Mills) from neutral to underperform," said analyst Bryan Spillane in a note. "We believe that with the stock's recent performance along with its premium multiple, (it) will need to deliver earnings upside over the next few quarters to move the stock higher. In our view, this could be challenging, given the current operating environment, suggesting the stock is likely to underperform."

General Mills' stock last hit a new high in June and has been basing since then. A conservative, defensive name, it's not given to big swings. During this base-building period, the stock has corrected only 13% from a high of 55.64.

The food-making giant grows slowly. The five-year annualized earnings growth rate is 6% with an Earnings Stability Factor of 2 on a 0 to 99 scale where low numbers correspond to steady earnings growth.
After two quarters in which year-over-year earnings grew 24% and 27%, EPS fell 4% in the most recent report.
Analysts are forecasting an 8% increase in the next report.
Analysts are expecting earnings to be flat in 2015, with 7% growth in 2016.
Pretax profit margins in 2014 were a healthy 14.6%, roughly in line with recent years.
But revenue has been falling. The past four quarters, it's fallen in the low single digits.
General Mills pays a quarterly dividend of 41 cents a share, which works out to an annualized yield of 3.1%.

First it was a recall of nut butters on salmonella concerns. Then a fire damaged a rice factory. And if that didn't hurt Hain Celestial Group enough since last summer, weak foreign currencies provided a third kick.
On a more personal level, CEO Irwin Simon had to have knee surgery in January to repair torn ligaments from an accident.

Through it all, Hain Celestial (HAIN) has generally seen its stock climb the past few years — barring periodic gyrations, such as Feb. 9's 3% dip as the overall market fell on concerns over Greece and China.
Hain stock is up 41% from an August low, including a 5.4% jump on Feb. 4 after second-quarter earnings were reported, bringing the stock back from a January lull.

While slower than expected, net sales in Hain's December-ending second quarter of fiscal 2015 were still up 31% to an adjusted $701.7 million. Adjusted earnings rose 26% to 54 cents per share, beating views.
Whole Package
A big part of Hain's appeal is its focus on the healthy side of the packaged-goods business.

It's behind some of the biggest brands in herbal tea (Celestial Seasonings), soy milk (WestSoy), organic baby food (Earth's Best), natural soups and cereals (Health Valley), healthy snacks (Terra) and cold-pressed juices (BluePrint), to name some of the many niches the company plays in.

"Demand remains strong across all channels for natural-organic foods," said analyst Scott Van Winkle of Canaccord Genuity. "And given that Hain is a multibrand, multicategory business, it is going to participate in the growth across all channels."
CEO Simon likes to say that his company has brand offerings in 10 of the top 15 highest-penetrated organic and natural product categories. Plus, he says, it has more than 500 gluten-free products.

Van Winkle credits management for working efficiently through good and tough times. In Hain's September-ending first quarter — which included its voluntary nut-butter recall in August — Hain grew earnings and revenue more than 30% vs. the year-earlier period.

And second-quarter earnings beat views despite interrupted production from fire damage at its Tilda specialty-rice factory in the U.K. in late October, which contributed to slower than expected sales.
Hain lowered its full-year outlook to reflect the multiple headwinds, including a $70 million impact from weaker foreign currencies and $20 million from the nut butter recall and fire.
The firm expects total net sales for the year ending in June of $2.650-$2.675 billion, up 23% to 24% over the prior fiscal year. Earnings are seen rising 17%-19% to $1.85-$1.89 per share.
Analysts see revenue growing 24% to $2.671 billion and earnings going up 18% to $1.88, according to a poll by Thomson Reuters.
"The recall is behind them at this point," Van Winkle said. "But the manufacturing challenges from the fire at the Tilda facility are going to take a few quarters to work through."
Hain bought U.K.-based Basmati and specialty-rice company Tilda in January 2014. It was one of numerous acquisitions made since its founding in 1993 and the first of three in 2014.

The other two last year were Rudi's Organic Bakery and the 51.3% interest that it didn't already own in organic poultry brands FreeBird and Plainville Farms — part of its Hain Pure Protein subsidiary.
High-Profile Customers
Hain Pure Protein sells to Panera Bread (PNRA) and Chipotle (CMG), among other customers.

"Hain's ability to complete accretive and synergistic M&As (mergers and acquisitions) has been a key reason for its success in recent years," said David Palmer, an analyst with RBC Capital Markets, in a research note on Feb. 5.

As one example, Palmer noted that sales of snack-focused Sensible Portions, which Hain acquired in 2010, grew 51% for the 12-week period ending January 2. That was up from 42% growth in the prior 12-week period.
Hain competes with numerous companies. They range from small organic and natural-foods players to the big packaged-goods giants that have increasingly been adding healthier products to their mix.
General Mills (GIS), for example, acquired organic snack and convenient-meals provider Annie's Homegrown in October. Campbell Soup (CPB) bought organic baby products company Plum Organics in 2013.
"Dozens if not hundreds of companies are their competitors," Van Winkle said. "This isn't General Mills against Kellogg (K) in the cereal aisle. This is a multibrand company in a rising category."
WhiteWave Foods (WWAV), for instance, is a rival in soy milk and organic dairy milk.
Traditional supermarkets such as Safeway and Kroger (KR), mass merchants Wal-Mart (WMT) and Target (TGT), and natural-organic grocer Whole Foods (WFM) and others in its category carry Hain products.
Hain's largest single customer is United Natural Foods (UNFI), a distributor to Whole Foods and other stores. Hain's products are sold in more than 65 countries.

The U.K. is Hain's second largest market after the U.S. Second-quarter net sales in the U.K. jumped 38% vs. the year prior to $200.8 million. Tilda contributed around $50 million of the total, even with the ongoing production disruption from the fire.
U.S. net sales rose 8% to $354 million. The nut-butter recall cut into sales by $5.3 million. Rudi's added $16.1 million.
Hain saw double-digit growth in several brands, including Sensible Portions, The Greek Gods, Terra, Garden of Eatin', Imagine and WestSoy, among others.
In a Q2 conference call on Feb. 4, Simon said that business had been strong in January. He alluded to cold-weather favorites such as tea, soup and snacks.

"We love cold weather and we love snowstorms," he said.First it was a recall of nut butters on salmonella concerns. Then a fire damaged a rice factory. General Mills (GIS) reported a drop in second-quarter earnings and revenue Wednesday, with sales below analyst expectations. The maker of cereal, yogurt and snacks said Q2 earnings fell 3.6% to 80 cents per share. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters were expecting 77 cents. Sales fell 3.4% to $4.71 billion, under views for $4.79 billion. Sales at the snacks and yogurt…
All eyes are back on organic and natural foods makers now that General Mills (GIS) has completed its buy of Annie's, first announced on Sept. 8.

The Minneapolis-based company paid $46 a share for the maker of Cheddar Bunnies, fruit snacks and mac 'n' cheese, a move it hopes will help revive flagging sales. Toward that effort, General Mills also disclosed in a late-September regulatory filing plans to cut 700 to 800 jobs, primarily in the U.S.

General Mills on Sept. 17 reported fiscal Q1 results that missed forecasts, sending its stock down more than 4%. It cited a 5% sales drop in its U.S. retail unit amid tougher competition from private-label brands as well as alternative breakfast foods.
The packaged food giant's brands include Cheerios, Wheaties, Betty Crocker, Haagen-Dazs, Progresso and Yoplait. It has been expanding overseas in recent years, with purchases in Brazil and India.

The firm's annual per-share earnings have increased between 3% and 16% the past eight years. It earns a 2 for its three- and five-year Earnings Stability Factor on a scale that runs from 0 (most stable) to 99 (most volatile).
Analysts expect profit growth to continue with a 5% increase to $2.97 a share for the fiscal year ending in May, plus a 7% rise to $3.18 in fiscal 2016.

Sales growth slowed the past two years from 12% to 7% to 1%. Consensus estimates call for a pickup to 3% in fiscal 2015. General Mills' earnings and sales growth rate for both the three- and five-year periods is 6%.
Its current quarterly dividend payout is 41 cents a share, or $1.64 on an annual basis, which works out to a yield of 3.2%. That's ahead of the S&P 500's 1.9%.

The stock has been working on a flat base since marking a new high on June 5. It's still trading below its 200-day and 50-day moving average line, where it's been meeting upside resistance. In the aftermath of "World Black Monday," how are the best-quality dividend payers on the S&P; 500 doing?
Not terribly bad, actually.

IBD wanted to see how many names within the 500 components of the key stock benchmark are flat or up for the year in price, produce a dividend yield of 1% or more, and showed profit growth in the latest quarter.
A total of 66 companies make the list.

What if you whittled the list down to those with a yield of 2.20% (matching the 500's yield) or greater? And you also required a minimum 10% EPS increase in the latest quarter and positive growth expected for the current fiscal year? The list shrinks to 14.
Here's a quick look at those elite large caps with exceptional earnings stability. On a scale of zero (most stable) to 99 (most volatile), they must score 25 or less.

GameStop (GME), the video game chain, shows a 3.3% annualized yield. The Grapevine, Texas, firm raised its payout twice since March 2014. The stock is trading just 7% off its 52-week high and up 30% year-to-date.

Valero Energy (VLO) is 19% off its 52-week peak, but still up 16% since Jan. 1. Full-year profit is seen up 25% to $8.27 a share. The yield is 2.7%. The three-year EPS Stability Factor is decent at 17.
This column profiled Leggett & Platt (LEG), which specializes in furniture internal mechanisms, in Monday's IBD.Reynolds American (RAI) has been featured 10 times in 2015.

Altria Group (MO) (5-year EPS Stability Factor 1, 4.3% yield), Eli Lilly (LLY) (5-year 9, 2.5%), Darden Restaurants (DRI) (3-year EPS Stability of 24, 3.3% yield), Equinix (EQIX) (3-year 25, 2.6%), Avery Dennison (AVY) (5-year 4, 2.6%), Essex Property Trust (ESS) (no EPS factor available, 2.7%), Carnival (CCL) (3-year 15, 2.6%), General Mills (GIS) (5-year 2, 3.2%), Public Storage (PSA) (no factor, 3.4%) and AvalonBay Communities (AVB) (no factor, 3.0%) also make the grade. A number of top-rated stocks hit new highs Thursday, but a couple didn't finish so hot. General Mills (GIS) turned tail after rising as much as 1.2%. It gave up 0.04 to 57.05 in another busy session. Intraday, the stock eked out an all-time high and nearly hit a 57.83 buy point from a flat base.

While not exactly a fast mover, General Mills staged a big upside reversal in Wednesday's session after giving mixed fiscal fourth-quarter results. It turned a near 3% loss into a gain of more than 2% in its busiest session since September. The maker of cereals and packaged foods delivered earnings that topped views, but sales missed expectations due to a strong dollar.
The company is planning gluten-free versions of five of its Cheerios varieties for release later this summer. Gluten-free Lucky Charms will be out later in the year.

In response to the trend toward healthier eating, the company announced last week that it is getting rid of artificial colors and flavors from its large line of cereals. Besides Cheerios and Lucky Charms, General Mills makes Cinnamon Toast Crunch, Kix, Wheaties, Count Chocula, Trix and other cereals.
General Mills already had been making a push to more healthy foods. Last year, it bought organic foods maker Annie's Homegrown for $280 million.
New issue Gener8 Maritime (GNRT) also finished off its session high and barely kept its win streak intact.

It added 0.02 to 13.75 for its fifth straight gain. Shares were up 2% at Thursday's high. The stock came public June 25. Gener8 sold 15 million shares at 14 each, which was below an expected range of 17 to 19.

The stock has yet to form a base. But it bears watching for a potential IPO base down the line. IPO bases can be shorter than conventional patterns such as cup-with-handle or double-bottom bases, which require at least seven weeks to form.

New York-based Gener8 provides crude oil transportation services through a fleet of 46 tankers. The company lost money in the past two years, but reported net income of $30.9 million in the first quarter.
No estimates are yet available for the company.
